James Parker Blvd. in Red Bank) and the rest can be from your home. Date/time of in-office work is flexible, can work with your schedule. Some data entry/computer experience is helpful. Training will be provided. Looking to start ASAP!
07701.title: Data Entry Volunteers

07701.description: DESCRIPTION: Move for Hunger, a national hunger-relief 501(c)3 organization, seeks a creative, talented, and enthusiastic videography and production intern. The selected candidate will work directly with the Art Director, Executive Director, and Communications Manager to create videos that will help raise awareness about hunger. This is a great opportunity for any self-motivated candidate looking to build their portfolio. TIME COMMITMENT: 2-4 days/week. Minimum 10 hrs/week in our Red Bank office. Part-time availability during the semester. Additional remote hours may be needed for editing. REQUIREMENTS/QUALIFICATIONS: Knowledge and experience with Adobe Premiere & AfterEffects Familiarity with Adobe Photoshop & Illustrator Experience with graphic design a plus** Experience with 2D and/or 3D animation a plus** Must be able to work cohesively and collaborate in a team environment Must be organized, detail oriented, proactive, and deadline-driven A portfolio that showcases your many talents (required with interview) Open to constructive feedback Candidate must use his/her own laptop during the course of the internship - however, extra monitor will be provided Must have a great understanding of our mission, goal, and audience DUTIES & RESPONSIBILITIES: Duties and responsibilities will vary from day to day, however, possibilities include the following: Lead and/or assist with the production of all video and media projects Assist in selecting, organizing, and editing footage Collaborate with other teams to arrange video shoots Produce dynamic content for YouTube & social media channels Produce branded stock video openings & closings Develop storyboard ideas for new content and videos Combine Animation & Video Local off-site shooting Absorb creative direction while bringing unique ideas and a point of view to the table Attend brainstorm sessions and video meetings Adhere to Move For Hunger’s brand and style guide Perform additional administrative tasks as needed, assigned by the Art Director COMPENSATION: This is an Unpaid/Volunteer internship TO APPLY: Please send a cover letter, resume, and portfolio to intern@moveforhunger.org, with the subject line \"VIDEOGRAPHY & PRODUCTION INTERNSHIP\"
07701.title: Videography & Production Internship | Fall 2018

07701.description: DESCRIPTION: Move For Hunger, a national hunger-relief 501(c)3 organization, seeks a dynamic, self-starter interested in learning about new media, also known as social media, communications. This internship is an excellent opportunity to experience how social media is used in a professional, non-profit setting, while working for an exciting young award-winning hunger-relief organization. TIME COMMITMENT Minimum 2-3 days/week Minimum 14 hrs/week in our Red Bank office REQUIREMENTS/QUALIFICATIONS: Freshman, Sophomore, Junior, Senior, or graduate level students, or recent college graduates Preferred Majors: Communication, Journalism, Media Studies, Digital Communication, Public Relations, Marketing, English, Health Studies, Social Work, Public Health, Non-profit Management, Business Administration MS Office Proficiency Social Media Proficiency Excellent written and oral communication skills Outgoing Personality with outstanding interpersonal skills Interest in learning more about social media strategy DUTIES & RESPONSIBILITIES: This position will work directly with the Communications Manager and Director of External Affairs. Duties and responsibilities will vary from day to day, however, possibilities include the following: Assist in planning and executing social media campaigns Identify and track social media coverage Maintain knowledge of current events and trends within hunger relief and food waste fields Assist in developing social media strategies for a variety of goals Amplify website content through social media posts Assist in developing, organizing, and implementing awareness and giving campaigns Assist program directors with operational initiatives and member communications COMPENSATION: This is an Unpaid/Volunteer internship TO APPLY: Please a send cover letter and resume to intern@moveforhunger.org, with the subject line \" NEW MEDIA COMMUNICATIONS INTERNSHIP\"
07701.title: New (Social) Media Communications Internship | Fall 2018

07701.description: DESCRIPTION: Move For Hunger, a national hunger-relief 501(c)3 organization, seeks a dynamic, self-starter interested in learning about marketing and relationship management to join their Programming Team. The Program Management Intern will help expand the organization’s network of moving companies, real estate professionals, and corporate housing providers by supporting the Programming Team with member recruitment, engagement, participation, communications, and encouraging the network to collect food for communities across the United States and Canada. This internship is an excellent opportunity for a student or professional interested in gaining experience in customer relations, marketing, membership management, and non-profit organizational processes, while working for a young award-winning hunger-relief organization. TIME COMMITMENT: 2-3 days/week Minimum 14 hrs/week in our Red Bank office REQUIREMENTS/QUALIFICATIONS: College or graduate level students, recent graduates, or professionals looking to change careers MS Office Proficiency Excellent written and oral communication skills Proactive and self-motivated, yet team-oriented Superior organizational skills and attention to detail Outgoing Personality with outstanding interpersonal skills Interest in making a difference in the community DUTIES & RESPONSIBILITIES: Duties and responsibilities will vary from day to day, however, possibilities include the following: Assist with recruitment efforts to expand the Move For Hunger network Assist with member retention and participation campaigns Assist with high volume telephone and email communications with new and existing members Data entry, such as recording food donations or researching food banks Writing and executing social media posts Managing, organizing, and executing mailings, including thank you letters and welcome kits COMPENSATION: This is an Unpaid/Volunteer internship TO APPLY: Please a send cover letter and resume to intern@moveforhunger.org, with the subject line \" PROGRAM MANAGEMENT INTERNSHIP\"
07701.title: Program Management Internship | Fall 2018

07701.description: Move for Hunger, a national hunger-relief 501(c)3 organization, seeks a creative, motivated, enthusiastic candidate interested in learning more about professional graphic design. The selected candidate with work directly with the events and communications team to help raise awareness about hunger through event fliers, posters, banners, info graphics, and images for social media. REQUIREMENTS/QUALIFICATIONS: Extensive knowledge and experience with Adobe Photoshop, Illustrator, and Indesign Must be able to work cohesively in a team environment and collaborate Must be organized, detail oriented, and able to meet deadlines Photography, Microsoft Office knowledge, videography, Adobe Premiere, Adobe AfterEffects are a plus A portfolio that showcases your many talents (required with interview) Be open to constructive feedback Working in a team oriented environment Candidate must use his/her own laptop during the course of the internship DUTIES & RESPONSIBILITIES: Tasks include but are not limited to: Creating visual content for website and individual posts to our blog/ events section Creating flyers, banners, posters, and marketing materials for food drives and other events Creation of layout and design for internal and external collateral materials Creation of info graphics for social media canpaigns Input into layout redesign of existing material Attending brainstorm sessions and communication/design meetings Adhering to Move For Hunger's brand and style guide Perform additional administrative tasks as needed, assigned by the Art Director TO APPLY: Please send cover letter, resume, and portfolio to intern@moveforhunger.org with the subject line \" GRAPHIC DESIGN INTERNSHIP\"
07701.title: Graphic Design Internship | Fall 2018

07701.description: DESCRIPTION: Move For Hunger, a national hunger-relief 501(c)3 organization, seeks a dynamic, self-starter interested in learning about non-profit administration, to assist with development, marketing, event planning, and communications efforts. This internship is an excellent opportunity to experience various aspects of non-profit administration while working for an exciting young award-winning hunger-relief organization. TIME COMMITMENT: 2-3 days/week Minimum 14 hrs/week in our Red Bank office REQUIREMENTS/QUALIFICATIONS: Freshman, Sophomore, Junior, Senior, or graduate level students, or recent college graduates Preferred Majors: Communication, Journalism, Media Studies, Digital Communication, Public Relations, Marketing, English, Health Studies, Social Work, Public Health, Non-Profit Management, Business Administration MS Office proficiency Excellent written and oral communication skills Outgoing personality with outstanding interpersonal skills Interest in making a difference in the community DUTIES & RESPONSIBILITIES: Duties and responsibilities will vary from day to day, however, possibilities include the following: Help plan and facilitate food drives and fundraisers, incorporating members and media promotion, as appropriate Assist with the identification and development of member engagement opportunities Create, promote, and maintain fundraising campaign Research current trends within the hunger relief and food waste fields Contribute to social media and web site content Assist with events that may occur locally and help recruit volunteers COMPENSATION: This is an Unpaid/Volunteer internship TO APPLY: Please a send cover letter and resume to intern@moveforhunger.org, with the subject line \" EVENT MANAGEMENT INTERNSHIP\"

10029.description: DREAM, an award winning youth development program, is seeking volunteer T-ball coaches to work with youth ages 5-7 in practices and games. Coaches teach T-ball and provide youth with opportunities to play, learn and grow; inspiring them to recognize their potential and realize their dreams. Each coach serves as a member of a small coaching staff. There are powerful rewards gained from the DREAM coaching experience. DREAM volunteer coaches can have a direct and noticeable impact on the positive development of the youth they coach. The ideal candidate is passionate about youth development, has experience working with youth, and can commit to attending six Saturday practices and games in July/August, as well as a one-day pre-season coaches training in June. Roles and Responsibilities: Guide a team of 16-18 youth through practices and games; Ensure youth safety on the field; Provide a fun and positive, team-based environment; Attend all practices and games on six Saturdays in July and August. Qualifications: Passionate about youth development; Understand the power of teamwork; Have the ability to create a positive, team-based environment focused on teaching T-ball; Organized, energetic and flexible; Skilled communicators; Experience in baseball/softball a plus; Able to commit to six Saturdays, in July and August; At least 18 years of age. Hours: Coaches conduct practices and games for an hour and a half on six Saturday mornings or afternoons from 7/7/18 to 8/11/18. Coaches must be able to commit to attend all six Saturday coaching sessions during the summer, as well as the coach training day in June. DREAM provides equal opportunity for all volunteers.
10029.title: Volunteer T-Ball Coaches!

10026.description: GiGi's Playhouse NYC is a Down Syndrome Achievement Center based in Harlem and serving the 5 boroughs. During the summer, we offer a series of unique educational opportunities for the community to learn vital life skills and learn with their peers. Summer Horizons (ages 20+) is an educational and recreational summer program where participants with Down syndrome experience NYC, and practice important life and job skills, from navigating public spaces, to money management, all while socializing with their peers and visiting some of Manhattan's best cultural offerings. Volunteers are needed to work one-to-one with participants and guide them through the week. Prior experience preferred but not required. Partial week volunteering available, but priority will be given to those who can commit to the full week. Training provided.
10026.title: Summer Mentors for Adults with Down Syndrome
10026.org: GiGi's Playhouse, Down Syndrome Awareness Centers

10027.description: Volunteer with Behind the Book (www.behindthebook.org), a non-profit literacy organization that inspires New York City public school students to explore stories and empower their voices. Through our innovative programs, which are part of the class curricula, accomplished authors visit high-needs pre-K-12 classrooms to guide students in creating their own writing projects based on the theme of the author's book. You need no experience or training to volunteer. As a classroom coach, you'll support and encourage students as they work on their projects. This workshop needs your help at a school in Harlem, NYC. To sign up, reply with the program code to volunteer@behindthebook.org. We'll supply the address, directions, and other information when you're confirmed: Program 15445LCR-731 Date: Tuesday, July 31st Time: 8:45 - 10:30 AM Volunteer Role: Writing Coach About the program: With Lesa Cline-Ransome 's Germs: Fact and Fiction, Friends and Foes , a picture book about the world of micro-organisms as narrated by a bacterium, fourth- and fifth-graders will explore the history and science of germs. They’ll also learn with the author about writing from a different perspective. With the guidance of coaches, students will craft pieces written from the perspective of a germy object they’ve chosen. For information on other programs around the city, please visit http://www.behindthebook.org/current-volunteer-opportunities/ To join our team and receive announcements of new programs as they're scheduled, please complete our brief questionnaire at http://www.behindthebook.org/join-us/volunteer/
10027.title: Writing coach for Harlem, NYC public school literacy program (154lcr)

10027.description: Volunteer with Behind the Book (www.behindthebook.org), a non-profit literacy organization that inspires New York City public school students to explore stories and empower their voices. Through our innovative programs, which are part of the class curricula, accomplished authors visit high-needs pre-K-12 classrooms to guide students in creating their own writing projects based on the theme of the author's book. You need no experience or training to volunteer. As a coach, you'll support and encourage students as they work on their projects. This program needs your help in Harlem, NYC. To sign up, contact volunteer@behindthebook.org with the program code. We'll supply the address, directions, and other information when you're confirmed. Program 1255AK-A2 Date: Thursday, August 2nd Time: 10:30 AM - 12:00 PM Volunteer Role: Writing coach About the program: Sixth-graders will read Francisco’s Kites by Alicia Klepeis, about a young boy who taps his ingenuity to build unique kites. The class will visit the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum to explore the basics of aerodynamics, then apply what they’ve learned to build their own kites from found objects and conduct a test flight. Coaches will work with small groups of students as they polish their explanatory essays based on facts from the book, field trip, and their experience creating and flying their own kites. For dates of other workshops around New York City, please visit our volunteer opportunities page at http://www.behindthebook.org/current-volunteer-opportunities/ To join our team and receive announcements of new classroom programs and other opportunities as they're scheduled, please complete our brief questionnaire at http://www.behindthebook.org/join-us/volunteer/
10027.title: Writing coach for Harlem, NYC public school literacy program (125ak)

10027.description: Artistic Noise Board of Directors Job Posting Job Description: As we enter our 18th year at Artistic Noise we are seeking new board members to support our organization’s growth. From our roots as a small program fiscally sponsored by an umbrella non-profit at Boston College, we have grown to become an independent 501(c)(3) organization. We moved from the \"incubator\" to \"startup\" phase in 2010, and now are building out more robust infrastructure to ensure we can offer our programs to more youth in need. Our mission is narrowly focused and we are experts at the work we do having refined our programmatic model over our 18 years. That said, we need our board to support the business of running a nonprofit, by Sharing their professional expertise and advice, Providing philanthropic support, Actively connecting Artistic Noise to the right people, resources, and partnerships. We ask that board members make a commitment of 3 years to Artistic Noise and participate in quarterly board meetings and committee meetings as needed. Candidates should be located in the Greater Boston or NYC areas. Desired Qualifications and Responsibilities: Participate in at least one of the standing committees (Governance, Finance, Development, Strategic Planning) Actively fundraise for the organization through your personal giving, networks, and more broadly. Have 3+ years experience in either the nonprofit or corporate sectors. Have experience/expertise in at least one of the following areas: finance, accounting, marketing, development, public relations, law. Some prior board experience preferred, but not required. This is a volunteer, unpaid position. Believe in the mission of Artistic Noise. About Artistic Noise: Mission and Purpose Artistic Noise exists to bring the freedom and power of artistic practice to young people who are incarcerated, on probation, or otherwise involved in the justice system. Through visual arts and entrepreneurship programs in Massachusetts and New York, our youth artists give voice to their experiences, build community through collaborative projects, and learn valuable life and job skills. Artistic Noise creates safe spaces where court-involved youth can be seen, heard and supported on their path to adulthood. We believe the practice of making art offers opportunities for young people and communities to transform. About our Programs By working with youth both in state custody and back in the community, Artistic Noise provides continuity for young people who are often experiencing trauma and upheaval in their lives. Our staff of teaching artists and licensed art therapists works with our participants to create safe, challenging spaces for creative expression. Using a variety of artistic mediums, youth explore themes such as friendship, loss, sexual violence, community, freedom, identity and their dreams for the future. This structured artmaking fosters critical thinking and problem solving skills that are beneficial to the teens' healthy psychological development. https://www.artisticnoise.org/ How to apply: Please submit your resume/cover letter to tamara.scarlett@artisticnoise.com and/or Amanda.holm@artisticnoise.com
10027.title: Artistic Noise seeks new member for Board of Directors

Through our innovative programs, which are part of the class curricula, accomplished authors visit high-needs pre-K-12 classrooms to guide students in creating their own writing projects based on the theme of the author's book. You need no experience or training to volunteer. As a coach, you'll support and encourage students as they work on their projects. This program needs your help in Harlem, NYC. To sign up, contact volunteer@behindthebook.org with the program code. We'll supply the address, directions, and other information when you're confirmed. Program 15423KB-724 Date: Tuesday , August 7th Time: 8:45 -10:30 AM Volunteer Role: Writing coach About the program: Second- and third-graders read My Mummy is an Engineer by Kerrine Bryan to learn about engineering and women in the fields of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). As they explore building their own structures, they’ll discover how engineers problem-solve. The class will also visit the New York Hall of Science Design Lab to learn more about structural design. Coaches will guide small groups in the classroom as they polish their writing about designing a structure featured in the book. For dates of other workshops around New York City, please visit our volunteer opportunities page at http://www.behindthebook.org/current-volunteer-opportunities/ To join our team and receive announcements of new classroom programs and other opportunities as they're scheduled, please complete our brief questionnaire at http://www.behindthebook.org/join-us/volunteer/
10027.title: Writing coach for Harlem NYC public school literacy program (154kb)

10027.description: The Sakura Park Festival is back in Morningside Heights for its second year! Neighbors of every age will enjoy the sounds, moves, and tastes of our global community in the beautiful Sakura Park and on West 122nd Street between Claremont and Riverside. Volunteer Information: Volunteers will share community information, assist with event setup/breakdown, and direct participants. Volunteers will be split into two time slots. 12:00PM - 4:00PM & 4:00PM - 8:00PM. 12:00PM volunteers may be required to meet at our office (only a few blocks from the event). 4:00PM volunteers may meet us at Sakura Park during the festival. Please specify the time slot you are interested in. There will be FREE FOOD available for volunteers. For more information, visit the Eventbrite page: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/sakura-park-festival-tickets-36027957591 You can also find us on Facebook & Twitter for updates on the upcoming event: https://www.facebook.com/sakuraparkfestival/ https://twitter.com/sakuraparkfest
10027.title: Community Outreach at 2018 Sakura Park Festival

10027.description: Market Access Program Intern Start Small Think Big (Start Small) is a not-for-profit organization located in Harlem. Our mission is to help under resourced individuals build and sustain thriving businesses in order to increase their personal financial security and stimulate economic activity in underserved communities in New York City. We believe that entrepreneurship results in increased innovation and sustained economic growth for everyone, in particular, those most traditionally marginalized. The Market Access Program Intern will work with the Marketing Program Manager to assist our entrepreneurs with marketing and sales business needs. This includes developing resource guides, learning more about sales opportunities in NYC and online, and supporting our communications team with a social media strategy. Job Responsibilities shall include, but are not limited to: Assist in managing Start Small Think Big social media platforms, including creating and posting content, identifying influencers in the space, and responding to comments and questions received from entrepreneurs. Research and develop informative resource guides focused on assisting entrepreneurs in identifying and addressing business challenges and community resources necessary to increase business success. Support the Marketing Program Manager in delivering services, via workshops, consultations, and project-based relationships, this includes managing logistics of events, coordinating entrepreneur attendance, and all necessary follow-up calls. Assist in developing the evaluation rubrics used by volunteer marketing experts to help entrepreneurs identify weaknesses in their current marketing practices. Preferred Skills/Qualifications: Current undergraduate student with strong interest in writing, social media, and communications, nonprofit program management, or other related disciplines. High level of computer proficiency including familiarity with Google Applications, social media (Facebook, Instagram and Twitter) and MS Office. Knowledge of programs: Buffer and Canva a plus. Demonstrated commitment to inclusive community/economic development, social and economic justice work, and/or anti-poverty work. Excellent verbal and written communication skills, time management, and interpersonal skills; Highly organized, creative and self-motivated; a strong problem-solver and analytical/critical thinker; and Experience working in low-income and/or immigrant communities. TO APPLY: Submit resume to: Eliza Edge, Market Access Program Manager at eliza@startsmallthinkbig.org (include subject line: \"[your name] Market Access Program Intern.\" This position is unpaid, but may be used for course credit where appropriate. Minimum 10 hours/week at our office. Hours are flexible. Start Small Think Big is an equal opportunity employer with a standing policy of nondiscrimination. This means that all qualified persons are accorded an equal opportunity for employment or promotion without regard to actual or perceived race, religion, color, national origin, ancestry, disability, medical condition, marital status, sex, age, sexual orientation, gender identity or expression, family responsibility, personal appearance, genetic information, matriculation, or political affiliation.
10027.title: Market Access Program Intern

10027.description: The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that is working to make poverty a focus of U.S. foreign policy. The Editor is responsible for reviewing articles submitted by The Borgen Project’s national team of writers. Editors will also perform edits for articles appearing on BORGEN Magazine and The Borgen Project Blog. Our volunteer position is a part-time, work from home role. You can set your own schedule and specify how many hours per week you wish to work. - Edit and format articles submitted by national writers. - Work with writers to improve their articles. Qualifications: Must have great editing skills. Must be able to work independently and meet deadlines with very little supervision. Experience writing SEO friendly content is helpful, but not required. To apply: Please email a copy of your resume and two writing samples to hr@borgenproject.org
10027.title: Volunteer Editor- New York

10027.description: We need a web developer to build a new website for our Brain-based Holistic Training center in Harlem! It's an exciting new project we have and we want to put all our energy and passion into it. Unfortunately we don't have the funds to pay for a web designer so we would really appreciate it if you have the expertise and can donate your time to this exciting project. Please feel free to reach out with any questions. Thank you! Isabel
10027.title: Web designer for Holistic Training Center website

10024.description: Volunteer tutors needed for low-income students for summer session from 7/5/18-8/17/18. You will be matched one-to-one with a student for just two hours per week. Students range in age from 7-18 (entering 2nd grade through 12th grade). There are no weekend hours available.
10024.title: Summer Volunteer Tutors Needed!

10024.description: Love seniors? Love giving makeovers? Attend a makeover at Phelps House with our intern chapter this summer! No experience necessary! Just bring yourself and a positive attitude. GlamourGals is a nonprofit that organizes and inspires teen volunteers to provide ongoing companionship and complimentary beauty makeovers to women living in senior homes. GlamourGals creates a movement of compassionate teen leaders working to end elder isolation. Chapters are student-led and based in high schools (grades 9-12) and universities. We currently have over 100 chapters across the country. What you can do as a volunteer: Connect with seniors in your local community and improve their overall wellbeing Participate in makeovers to help seniors feel young again Provide seniors with a restored sense of dignity through personal attention and the warmth of caring touch Gain the opportunity to listen to and share their stories Bridge the gap between generations in your community What you will gain as a volunteer: Develop confidence and have the opportunity to take on leadership roles Gain access to mentorship opportunities, interactive skill-building workshops, and professional development training Improve your interpersonal and communication skills through interacting with seniors Receive support, guidance, and materials from the GlamourGals National Office for senior home visits Time Commitment: Join us whenever you can this summer for a 1.5 hour makeover visit Our scheduled visits will take place on: June 27 July 18 and 25 August 1 and 8 Visits take place at 1:00 - 2:30pm at Phelps House (Goddard Riverside Community Center) Check out our website to find out more about us! www.glamourgals.org Read our weekly blog posts about our volunteers' stories from their GlamourGals experiences! www.glamourgals.org/blog/
10024.title: NYC Senior Home Visit/Makeover

10025.description: Whether you're great, good or fair at Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM), you can help make an impact on inner-city youth. Here's how: The Parris Foundation S.T.E.M.ulating Minds Weekend Enrichment Program has returned for the Summer 2018 session. The program began after a successful summer pilot in 2012, and our subsequent programs have grown to continue to serve middle school students and high school students . With the growing impact on the community, we need your support to continue to bring STEM to our middle school and high school youth throughout New York City. As we expand to more locations to serve more youth, there is a growing need for volunteers! How we do it: The Parris Foundation curriculum combines innovative and interactive software and teaching techniques with hand-ons interdisciplinary experiments and activities to keep our students engaged with their passion for science and math! About The Parris Foundation: The Parris Foundation is dedicated to promoting educational opportunities and fostering awareness in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) through scholarships and community outreach programs. The Parris Foundation's S.T.E.M.ulating Minds: Weekend Enrichment Programs provide extended learning opportunities to supplement and enhance in-school learning.
10025.title: Summer 2018 - S.T.E.M.ulating Minds Weekend Enrichment Program

10025.description: Inspire Women to Travel Solo and deconstruct your expereince with others! Do you have useful tips, tricks, or special interests that will inspire people to hit the road? Can you discuss how your positionality impacted your experience traveling solo? If so, we’d love you to be a presenter at one of our monthly travel workshops. Presentations are free and open to the public, helping educate travelers about the benefits of travel, and how they may be perceived. Speakers will work with the Hostelling International USA Education Coordinator to: Create a brief one paragraph description of your travel experience that captures the essence of your travels Build an interactive 5 slide presentation with a slide show, food or anything you think helps the presentation resonate with attendees Deliver presentation to a group of about 5 up to 30 people, including questions from the audience. Workshops are held either at the New York Hostel or can be presented remotely at one of our partner sites. Presenters are welcome to create unique presentations of their own, or incorporate additional elements that will be useful. Sample presentations and general presentation tips are provided to all prospective travel presenters. Supporting our Mission: The travel workshop presenter, through savvy travel tips and cultural learning recommendations, helps inspires a genuine understanding of people, places and cultures for a more tolerant world. Requirements: Public speaking and presentation skills Passion for travel and teaching others to travel 2 hours per program Presenter must be available to present during the evening, typically on Wednesdays or Thursdays. To Apply: Please email Education Coordinator, Indigo Goodson at indigo.goodson@hiusa.org and visit http://www.volunteers.hiusa.org to fill out a form. Please provide: Best telephone number you can be reached for initial screening interview and best hours to reach you.
10025.title: Be a Women Traveling Solo 101 Presenter at HI NY!

10025.description: The New Jewiish Home, Manhattan Division has a wide variety of opportunities for high school and college students to volunteer with over the summer vacation. Opportunities vary and we will try our best to meet your interest Opportunities include but not limited to: Recreation Assistant (Bingo, Games, Exercise, Arts & Crafts, Nail Spa) Pharamacy (selective, limited spots) Library Assistant (upkeep of shelving, assisting book selections, assisting computer users) Clerical/Office Assistant Please apply online at the following link: https://www.volgistics.com/ex/portal.dll/ap?ap=1114206372 Please mention Volunteer Match & Summer Volunteering in your application If you have any questions - Please contact Jessica at JSinovoi@jewishhome.org

10023.description: Looking for a fun and rewarding day of volunteering? Join us for NCJW NY's Back 2 S chool Store on August 5th! NCJW New York is transforming Council House into a very special department store on Sunday, August 5th, and we need you! At the Back 2 School Store, 200 elementary school children from underserved communities will \"shop\" for everything they need to go back to school with pride and enthusiasm! All items are brand new and service is free of charge. We need your help! Each child will be assigned a personal shopper to guide them through the store. Personal shoppers are a crucial part of the Back 2 School Store experience and we hope you will join us! Other volunteer opportunities include: registration, inventory, floor staff, and Family Resource Center. We also have volunteer opportunities in the weeks leading up to the store to help with data entry, set up, inventory and packing up after the store. Please email azadoff@ncjwny.org for more information and to get involved.
10023.title: Personal Shopper for the 2018 Back 2 School Store!
10023.org: National Council of Jewish Women NY Section

10023.description: We are seeking enthusiastic, creative, industrious, responsible, punctual, and best of all, creative people who can generate fun every moment of the STEM summer day camp experience. Depending upon your experience, you will work as a STEM Teacher, STEM Junior Teacher, Head Counselor, or Group Leader in the classroom, in offsite locations, or in the gymnasium/outdoor playground. Must have tons of energy, a willingness to make a fool of yourself for the sake of making someone smile, the ability to give \"warm fuzzies\" on a daily basis, and a desire to have FUN! If you have experience in any of the following, this camp is for you: visual art, music, dramatic art, mad science, coding, maker faire, financial literacy, entrepreneurship, community service, activism, literacy, education, chess, juggling, sports, yoga, fire throwing, marching band, drill team, gardening, cooking, learning, sharing the love and joys of learning and making friends with children.
10023.title: Teach kids how to code, engineer, and love Science!  Looking For STEM Summer Camp Teachers - NYC

We are seeking a volunteer to facilitate an English Conversation Group for our higher level English for Speakers of Other Languages students. The volunteer will be responsible to facilitating group discussion that encourages participants to practice their English speaking skills in a supportive environment. The Conversation Group will meet on Thursdays, 1:00-2:00, July 12 - August 30.

11743.description: Who doesn't love the warmth and unconditional love from a beautiful four legged furry pet? If you love dogs, and I mean, really love dogs then you can be part of a rewarding experience. Our exclusive Pet Therapy program is currently looking for chaperones. We have committed pet therapy handlers who bring their trained and certified dogs to the hospital to visit our patients. As a chaperone you will be . . . escorting the handler and dog to the patient floors on various units. engaging and interact with our patients & families and wonderful caregivers. providing hand sanitizer to all who pet the dog. greeting patients and introducing the pet handler and pet therapy dog. able to commit to one day a week for a maximum of 2 hours, usually not more than an hour. The presence of a dog in a hospital setting allows the patients to feel more at home, as they do play a small part of the healing process. The immediate gratification you will see on the patients' and staffs' faces when they are interacting with the dog is truly amazing. There are known benefits for pet therapy visits . . . improves mood and overall well-being decreases stress and anxiety lowers blood pressure lets patients reminisce about their own animals If you are interested in volunteering in our program, please contact me for an interview. Alice Messina Patient Liaison Pet Therapy Coordinator 631-351-2399 amessina2@northwell.edu
11743.title: Pet Therapy Chaperone

You must stay at your post at all times except for your lunch break and if there is a break between any of the classes. You will NOT be handling the cats. 07018.description: The Pearl Club has a mission to educate, empower and support young women to overcome poverty by fostering advanced educational pursuit. Through our programming, The Pearl Club University, we strive to empower young women to overcome poverty by attaining a post-secondary degree. The position of the Board of Directors is a voluntary position that serves as the leadership, sustainability and growth of the organization. In this role, there are three focuses: Strategic Oversight: approve annual budgets, strategic plans and review and measure outcomes; provide strategic leadership Sustainability: actively participate in fundraising initiatives, see this as a philanthropic priority and assist in identifying board members and contribute to the annual performance of ED Commitment: actively participate and attend board meetings and take a proactive approach to the growth of the organization Within these three focuses, the Board of Directors is responsible for the following: Actively attend board meetings, including preparing for meetings Strong commitment to the organization's mission and purpose by acting as a brand ambassador and connecting/extending the organization to your network and beyond Open, honest and unbiased communication Thorough decision making that aligns with the mission, is student- and future-focused Actively participate in board fundraising goals and organizational fundraising initiatives Think outside of the box to produce outcomes, develop relationships, generate partnerships and provide opportunities for young women Stay current on important trends that relate to their expertise as it relates to the growth and success of the organization Be inspired to share their involvement with their networks to garner support and build relationships, including inviting them to all events and providing contacts to include in our email distribution lists Willingness to step out of comfort zone to produce outcomes, including trainings and professional development We are looking for someone with the following: Experience launching and building a new brand/organization Interest in growing a sustainable organization Connected to Education + corporations Experience with Fundraising, Leading and planning initiatives Provide strategic leadership experience A desire to be hands-on w/high level of initiative
07018.title: Join Our Board of Directors

11238.description: Work with Adult Literacy Students at one of the five Brooklyn Public Library Learning Centers. Help them reach their personal goals. Lead reading and writing activities for small groups of adult learners who read below the fifth grade level. Assist them in using technology. We provide a 20 hour Volunteer Tutor Training where you will learn the BPL’s Literacy Program’s philosophy, how to use the library’s resources for instruction, and how to create effective lesson plans. Professional staff will encourage your development in this richly rewarding field. Volunteers must have a high school diploma or equivalent and a love of reading and writing. Volunteers are asked for a one year commitment to tutoring either 2 - 2 hours sessions, or 1 - 3-hour session per week. To learn more about the Brooklyn Public Library Learning Centers, please visit the BPL website at http://www.bklynpubliclibrary.org. To register to attend an Information Session, click here.

10562.description: What does the Parent Child Together Program Do? Parent Child Together provides parents with peer-to-peer learning opportunities with a focus on positive parenting skills, early childhood development and school readiness. While the parents learn, the children participate in activities within the classroom covering shapes, colors, numbers, letters, pre literacy concepts as well as helping them gain the social emotional and self regulation skills needed prior to entering Kindergarten. What do the Volunteers Do? In the first hour the parents and children work separately and at this point, staff and volunteers help the children with separation and also carrying out the activities for the hour. In the second hour, parents and children come together for activities and the role of the staff and volunteers at this point, is to model techniques for struggling parents and assist when a parent has more than one child in the program. We ask for a minimum commitment of 6 months - if possible (there is flexibility for vacations etc.)
10562.title: Parent Child Together program volunteer in Ossining

10019.description: Estamos buscando un voluntario para acompañar a un encantador señor de 90+ años. Él vive en la parte sureste de la ciudad de New York. A él le encanta jugar domin ó , mirar noticias y novelas. Él te necesita solo una hora a la semana. GRACIAS. We match isolated and lonely seniors with volunteers in the community who make weekly visits in the senior’s home. The Friendly Visiting program is an opportunity to form rewarding relationships and ongoing companionship for both seniors and volunteers. Seniors and their visitor can converse and enjoy the company, take part in activities like going to cafes and museums, share stories, learn new skills, and a variety of other things based on the desires of the companions. You will be matched with a senior who has a similar personality and interests and you can decide together how to spend your time. Visits can easily fit into your schedule because matches are made based on your availability. We ask for a minimum commitment of 6 months or 1 year. Your time as a friendly visitor is invaluable, and you gain a new friend!
10019.title: Necisitamos Voluntario Para Acompañar Encantador Caballero De 90 Años - Adora Jugar Dominó ¡Gracias!

10018.description: Its important that in order to address the significant environmental challenges before us that we measure and report on our impact as a society. In our work with cities and communities, Global Green has crafted some impact goals and is using to communicate these goals internally, within our Board and also in external materials such as newsletters and on our website. Furthermore, by having cohesive national impact goals this will enable us to better coordinate across our 4 offices in Los Angeles, NYC, New Orleans and DC. We're seeking help from a graphic design professional to illustrate the impact goals below. These can be either done in an infographic style or more of a conceptual / symbolic style. Global Green's staff will meet with the volunteer in person (if in NYC) or by phone and discuss a strategy and then the volunteer will create the design. The graphics will be used for a number of purposes including internal communications, in our newsletter, on globalgreen.org and in annual reports or other reporting.
10018.title: Graphic Design Volunteer Needed to Illustrate Measurable Impact Goals
10018.org: Coalition for Resource Recovery Global Green USA

10018.description: DESCRIPTION The Trevor Project is dedicated to recruiting qualified volunteers to provide life-saving, life-affirming support to lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer, and questioning (LGBTQ) youth. Our volunteers accomplish societal and individual change by creating safe spaces for LGBTQ youth in crisis and promoting awareness of Trevor’s resources. Trevor Lifeline volunteers are trained to answer calls on the Trevor Lifeline from young people who are feeling suicidal or need a safe, non-judgmental place to talk. This is an onsite volunteer opportunity and those interested need to live near our call centers which are located in LA. Time Commitment: **Note: Volunteers must be available for all training dates and times. Lifeline NY Updates July 2018 Lifeline Training: Orientation: Thursday, July 12th | 7:00 PM - 9:00 PM EST Training Dates: July 14-15th, 21-22nd (Sat/Sun) | 9:30 AM - 6:30 PM EST Post-Training: Thursday, August 23rd | 7:00 PM - 9:00 PM EST Trevor Lifeline Shift Times (we ask that volunteers commit to two 4-hour shifts per month): Sunday - Tuesday | 1:45pm - 6:00pm EST (New York) Wednesday - Thursday | 5:45pm - 10:00pm EST (New York) Friday - Saturday | 1:45pm - 6:00pm EST (New York) Required Skills and Qualifications: You are open to constantly learning. You are good at practicing self-care. You fit the profile of an ideal Lifeline volunteer: Genuine Empathetic Non-judgmental Empowering HOW TO APPLY **Please note: You must be at least 18 years old to volunteer. If you are under 18, please consider our Trevor Youth Ambassador Council. For more information, visit our website on trevorproject.org or reach out to our Community Engagement Coordinator Ashley Choi at Ashley.Choi@thetrevorproject.org.
10018.title: Trevor Project NY Lifeline Volunteer

10018.description: Fiver Children's Foundation is seeking two (2) efficient and detail-oriented Database Administrative Volunteers to join their team! Fiver;s Database Administrative Volunteers ill work with Fiver's Operations and Accounting Department i a fast-paced work environment. Responsibilities for this position include but or not limited to, recording important information about the participants who attended and will attend Camp Fiver, Fiver's Summer Residential Program. This information is crucial when evaluating the success of Camp Fiver, evaluating and seeking funding, scheduling of Camp Programs, and maintaining pertinent contact information about Fiver Families. Fiver's Database Administrative Volunteers will assist Fiver in making a positive impact on the lives of youth throughout New York City and Central New York by successfully fulfilling the responsibilities of the volunteer position. Responsibilities include: Review Camp Fiver 2018 Applications and Health Forms Enter and update information collected from Fiver's 2018 Camp Applications Check for accuracy regarding addresses, Program Stages and assigned Session for each participant Conduct outreach for outstanding documents Any additional tasks related to this position as assigned Requirements for this position: Detail oriented Self-starter who can execute assignments independently A strong work ethic and sets high standards for his/her/their own work Strong organizational skills Analytical skills Experience with data entry and Excel preferred Language Skills Required: Spanish speaking preferred, but not required Fiver's Administrative Volunteers will: Attend a training on the software that will be used throughout the volunteer position Play a crucial role in a nonprofit that makes a 10-year commitment to youth throughout New York City and central New York and empowers them to make ethical and healthy life choices, become engaged citizens, and succeed in school, careers, and life. Be a member of a vibrant and divers team of staff members and volunteers Develop professionally through this volunteer position Assist Fiver Children's Foundation with the organization of information regarding Fiver participants who attended and will be attending Camp Fiver this summer Time Commitment: Must be able to commit a minimum of 10 - 15 hours on Monday, Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday Dates: May 2018 - August 2018 If you are interested in this volunteer opportunity, please email your resume to casie@fiver.org.
10018.title: Database Administrative Volunteer

07746.description: Ideal candidate will enjoy conducting research or be pursuing or have received a degree in Epidemiology, Biostatistics, or another field managing numbers or interested in a field where Market Research is essential. 07090.description: Have you ever been told you are a good listener? Are you looking for a flexible, rewarding volunteer opportunity? Are you an empty nester? Are you an active older adult with extra time on your hands? Do you have a yearning to really make a difference? Become a Caring and Crisis Hotline Listener. You could save a life. Volunteers receive 52 hours of comprehensive training in active listening, Mental Health First Aid and Applied Suicide Intervention Skills Training. You also are supported by seasoned listeners during 24 hours of internship before you answer calls on your own. Even once you are a certified listener, we provide a range of support and training opportunities so you can continue to develop your skills. Join our listening community. Our next volunteer training will be held: September 12, 2018 - December 12, 2018 7 pm - 10 pm One evening weekly Plus one full weekend - 12/1 and 12/2 Westfield Presbyterian Church 140 Mountain Ave, Westfield NJ 07090 Register Now! Registration is limited. Cost includes all materials and certifications for Mental Health First Aid and ASIST To learn more and apply, please log onto http://caringcontact.org/volunteer-listener-application/ or call 908.301.1899
07090.title: Become a Caring and Crisis Hotline Listener

10013.description: Since our inception, we have focused on one motto: We can all make a change. We may not be in a perfect position to help others, but we are all different. We can all teach and learn from one another as we go. Whether it is volunteering as a Teaching Artist with adults or children, assisting with language translation, volunteer coordination, social media & marketing, photography, web development, or sheer enthusiasm, we always welcome opportunities to grow together. Our weekly Creative Expression workshops with survivors and their children will take place every Friday from 12-4:30pm, starting July 20th-October 5th, 2018 with a culminating showcase on October 12th from 5-7pm. Contact us with your interests and availabilities and we can find what works best for you!
10013.title: Volunteer with arts workshops for survivors of domestic violence & sexual assault

10013.description: VOLUNTEER NEEDED FOR OUR MANHATTAN OFFICE INSIDE OF FEDCAP. DUTIES: --Greet the client --Explain that we take pictures and they have to sign a waiver [(we can cut their heads off on the picture, should they not want to be seen) Not mandatory for receiving services] --Measure assist them in tying a tie (if they do not know how) finding a suit, shirt, slacks, shoes, etc. that fits. (They can try on the clothing in the restroom.) --Arrange for the hemming of pants or the sewing on of buttons with the tailor and set a date for the client to pick up the tailored items. If no alterations are needed, then fold up the items and place in a bag for the client. --Keep records of activities and calls in the log. --Be able to work alone, with minimal supervision or with others We are doing one day a week, for now (date to be discussed), but the time will be 10 AM to 3 PM. This is a great opportunity for anyone wanting to go into law enforcement and who wants to see \"the other side\" after a person comes home, someone that wants to be in the fashion industry, or social services/non-profit sector. You will be networking with everyday people, politicians, individuals from different programs (formerly incarcerated individuals, etc.), City organizations/programs, and pastors. There is a possibility that you will be helping with administrative work and our events as well. You must be neat and presentable. We also will need you to assist in pop-up shops and the occasional donation pick up. Check out what we do to get a better feel for 100 Suits http://www.100suits.org/100-suits-speaks Please be reliable! SERIOUS INQUIRIES ONLY!!!
10013.title: Fashion and Justice Volunteer (Queens)

11231.description: Love to eat? Want to eat, drink, experience new restaurants, chefs, food establishment folks while doing good? Then, volunteer for our 4th Tastes of Brooklyn Carroll Gardens-Cobble Hill Summer Crawl - a Food Fest. You can join us anytime that day, to help set up, or work during the event, or breakdown. Event: Sunday, July 29 Time: 4-7 pm People buy tickets for 4 tastes for $20 or 11 tastes for $50 and walk along Court and Smith and Henry Streets in Brooklyn, below Atlantic Avenue, just off the F and G trains at Bergen and Carroll Streets. We need volunteers to buy a ticket at tastesofbrooklyn.com to support Seeds in the Middle (seedsinthemiddle.org) work to empower kids in central Brooklyn's food deserts to create healthy choices. In the past, we have had more than 20 restaurants taking part along Smith, Court and Henry Streets, between Atlantic Avenue and 4th Street in Carroll Gardens. We are still welcoming more for this event. What you can do! work beside chefs to serve food at restaurants or mark tickets lead a group tour (you'd need to gather info first about the restaurants first so you can talk about it - great experience for someone who wants to be a tour guide - email us at tastesofbrooklyn.com) lead a group of kids on a scavenger hunt (where they have to find clues at different restaurants and when they get all them, win a prize) work our youth-run Hip2B Healthy Market, where youth serve fresh OJ, parfaits, air-popped popcorn to show healthy snacks can be delicious! hand out flyers put up flyers help us advertise and sell tickets anything else you can think of to make this a success No experience needed. Just be reliable. You don't have to do the whole time, just volunteer at least two hours, preferably four. Email us at tastesofbrooklyn@gmail.com See the event at bit.ly/brooklynsummercrawl Join the event at : https://www.facebook.com/events/270771653660368/ Like Tastes of Brooklyn on Facebook Follow us on Instagram and Twitter. These wonderful restaurants are donating food to support kids in underserved neighborhoods. Help us show them love and build their small businesses, too.
11231.title: Cooks! Food Lovers Wanted -  July 29 in Carroll Gardens, BK Crawl

11231.description: Eat. Drink. For Good. Help us plan and expand Tastes of Brooklyn's Carroll Gardens-Cobble Hill Summer Crawl - scheduled for SUNDAY, JULY 29 TIME: 2-6 PM TICKETS: 4 tastes for $20, 11 tastes for $50 Supporting Seeds in the Middle's student-run Hip2B Healthy Markets, Chef Nights and edible gardens in schools, and our soccer program for at-risk and underserved children in central Brooklyn and beyond!!! We give community service credits, recommendation letters, you name it. Great for anyone looking to expand contacts in culinary and hospitality industries and just to intern this summer! Help us: Reach out to food and drink establishments from Atlantic Ave. south along Court, Henry, Smith Sts. Publicize in any way you know - help hand out flyers anywhere Social Media - post on food sites or just share on your Instagram, Snapchat, Facebook, etc. Get friends to buy tickets! Help chefs plan menus Day of - help chefs and participants Reach out to tourist businesses and encourage them to bring groups Day of and before - run Hip2B Healthy juice stands in neighborhood to show what we do If you like summer cocktails, help us organize a cocktail competition or something like that :) GUEST CHEFS WELCOME! If you love food and drink , like planning events, are organized, detail oriented and outgoing, please join us. Must be reliable. Email us at tastesofbrooklyn@gmail.com and tell us what you can do and when you are available. Ticket site: bit.ly/brooklynsummercrawl Website: tastesofbrooklyn.com
11231.title: Foodie? Chef? Event planner? Join Tastes of BK Carroll Gdns-Cobble Hill Crawl

10011.description: The Children’s Tumor Foundation is a non-profit organization dedicated to funding critical research that will one day end neurofibromatosis. In addition to benefiting those who live with NF, this research is also shedding new light on several forms of cancer, brain tumors, bone abnormalities, and learning disabilities, ultimately benefiting the broader community. The Children’s Tumor Foundation also supports people living with NF and their families with accurate, current and readily accessible information, and assists in the development of clinical centers to create better access to quality healthcare. We are in need of several committee members to join our team of NF Walk Organizers! The role of the committee member may be: To partner with and support the event chair in planning the event within the community. Help motivate, recruit and retain the participants. Communicate with the event Chair on a regular basis and be proactive in the community promoting the event. Assist with logistics and pre-event planning. Securing donations for a raffle, picnic and fundraising. Recruit and organize event-day volunteers. Assist with event-day activity planning and management and post event wrap up. Join the CTF Volunteer Team and see what a difference one person can make! Event site: https://join.ctf.org/event/2018-nf-walk-nyc/e163860
10011.title: New York Charity Walk Committee Members Needed - NYC

10011.description: The Children’s Tumor Foundation is a non-profit organization dedicated to funding critical research that will one day end neurofibromatosis. In addition to benefiting those who live with NF, this research is also shedding new light on several forms of cancer, brain tumors, bone abnormalities, and learning disabilities, ultimately benefiting the broader community. The Children’s Tumor Foundation also supports people living with NF and their families with accurate, current and readily accessible information, and assists in the development of clinical centers to create better access to quality healthcare. We are in need of an event chair to lead our organizational committee! Position Summary: Serve as the Lead Event Organizer, overseeing the event from beginning to end. Organize/recruit, motivate and lead a committee of other volunteers as they recruit teams, obtain sponsorship, and plan the event details. Roles and Responsibilities Work with Operations Chair and Staff Partner to follow all Children’s Tumor Foundation policies and procedures as well as state laws and local ordinances as well as the program standards. Know and be able to articulate the CTF mission, vision and messaging points. Recruit volunteer committee leads to manage the various aspects of the event (such as: Media & Publicity, Logistics, Operations, Recruitment, Event Volunteers). Work with Staff Partner to schedule committee meeting dates, develop agendas and facilitate committee meetings. Monitor progress of committee chairs through regular communication to ensure tasks are completed. Enforce accountability with committee members for assigned tasks and the overall event goals. Adhere to pre-approved budget through work with Staff Partner. Assist with identification of the appropriate person to succeed you as Chair. Arrange for appropriate recognition of sub-committee members and event day volunteers. Preferred Skills and Experience: Previous fundraising event organization is preferred but not essential. Organizational skills including general organizing, planning, time management, scheduling, coordinating resources and meeting deadlines. Comfort speaking in front of a group or potential sponsor Excellent communication skills Ability or experience overseeing the work of others. Spreadsheet and/or Google Drive knowledge and experience is a plus. Event site: https://join.ctf.org/event/2018-nf-walk-nyc/e163860
10011.title: New York Experienced Event Organizer Wanted -NYC

10017.description: The New York City Poetry Festival invites poetry organizations and collectives of all shapes and sizes to bring their unique formats, aesthetics, and personalities to the festival grounds, which are ringed with a collection of beautiful Victorian houses and tucked beneath the wide, green canopies of dozens of century old trees. By uniting the largest community of poets in the country and offering a unique setting for literary activity, the New York City Poetry Festival electrifies arts and literature and brings poetry to new light in the public eye. Our volunteer opportunities include but are not limited to: customer service and hospitality, stage management, entry assistance, tech assistance, bartending and food service, photography and videography, etc. This event takes place on July 28th and 29th from 11am to 6pm on Governors Island in New York City.
10017.title: Volunteer at the 2018 New York City Poetry Festival

We're looking for fun-loving, optimistic people willing to lend a helping hand. The class has a number of students, and we want to ensure that each gets the attention they deserve. Volunteers will be responsible to make sure that every student is following directions, and help them learn the moves if needed. No ballet experience is required. The class is every Saturday at 10:00am starting on June 30, 2018-July 28, 2018. We're looking for 3-4 volunteers per week for the class. You can register to volunteer just once, or for numerous dates. Please find the volunteer application here: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeJKTu6_LpV3IyA_o7YcKpc9NHwI7O9JsfkE0dvEy1y5seQ9A/viewform

10016.description: Thanks so much for wanting to make a difference. We are recruiting volunteers to be group facilitators for children ages 5-17 (groups are divided according to age), as well as event and fundraising helpers. Please view below for the volunteer type requirements and descriptions. The family and children group sessions are held at two Manhattan school locations, midtown and harlem. I invite you to visit our website at www.acaringhand.org to learn more about us and to acquire an application: https://docs.wixstatic.com/ugd/ea9db3_572250eb6e1d4899bd0837d204ffdbe9.pdf. Feel free to contact me directly at RobinGoodman@acaringhand.org for more information or to send A Caring Hand application. View our video about our group program directly at https://vimeo.com/90184263 or on our website, acaringhand.org VOLUNTEER TYPES AND REQUIREMENTS 1) GROUP FACILITATORS: Group facilators must complete an application, have an interview, and attend a 8-12 hour training. One year commitment is required to co-facilitate the child and teen groups. 11 wee group session is held 3 times per year, summer, fall and winter ( Sept - June). A monthly drop in session is held Sept-June. Attendance at a 11 week session is a minimum requirement. In certain circumstances, a commitment for the monthly groups can be accommodated. Group facilitators are assigned to weekly groups during the weekdays and evenings. The days when groups are held vary from season to season. Currently groups are held on Tuesdays and Wednesdays, and our monthly groups are held on Thursdays. Indicate your best evening availability during the week. Groups are held at two Manhattan school locations, midtown and Harlem. 2) VOLUNTEER EVENT HELP: We rely on the generous donations from individuals, corporations, and grants to fund our work. We need a strong volunteer event committe to help with all aspects of our annual gala and other fundraising activities. 3) VOLUNTEER HELPER AND FUNDRAISING: We always need extra hand on deck for various short term projects throughout the year. The projects range from stuffing envelopes and answering phones to doing outreach in th community. Certainly if you have a particular skill aor specific time you would like to help out you should let us know. We also rely on volunteers to help with A Caring Hand, The Billy Esposito Foundation fundraising activities and other board projects. WE WELCOME VOLUNTEERS WITH A RANGE OF EXPERIENCE! APPLY TODAY! Follow this direct link: https://docs.wixstatic.com/ugd/ea9db3_572250eb6e1d4899bd0837d204ffdbe9.pdf or visit our website at www.acaringhand.org for an application.
10016.title: Volunteer Group Facilitators and Event Help Needed!

10014.description: The National Parks Conservation Association's (NPCA) Northeast office is seeking volunteers to join NPCA staff in tabling in Christopher Park to increase awareness regarding Stonewall National Monument. This summer, volunteers will be tabling near the Stonewall Inn in Christopher Park to answer questions and provide more information to the public about the recently designated Stonewall National Monument in Greenwich Village, the first National Park Service (NPS) site dedicated to LGBT history and the site of the 1969 uprisings that sparked the modern LGBT civil rights movement. Through the end of July, we plan to reach hundreds of visitors at Stonewall National Monument from 12-5pm on Mondays, Thursdays, and Sundays. Responsibilities: Talk to passers-by and share the story of Stonewall Discuss the recent designation of the Stonewall National Monument, and provide answers to basic questions Get feedback from visitors about their ideas for the future of Stonewall National Monument Maintain sign-up list for people interested in getting on the park's mailing list Direct the public to a website where they can learn more Set up and break down tabling materials Requirements: Be friendly and outgoing, ready to engage the public Interest in LGBT rights Available for 2 or 3 hour shifts Enjoy being outside Ability to lift table and chairs
10014.title: Stonewall National Monument Volunteers

11568.description: We are in need of a panel of Industry experts in the fields of Science, Technology, Engineering Arts, Math (STEAM) to inspire, motivate, educate students to enter these fields. You will be part of a panel of five or six people speaking about your career and how it relates to STEAM. Students will then be able to ask questions of you. You will need to commit your afternoon from 2:45pm- 4:00pm if selected. Panels will focus on themes throughout the week. With the following format: Monday - Science Tuesday - Technology Wednesday - Engineering Thursday - Arts Friday - Math All panelists must schedule a 30 minute interview with our volunteer management team prior to being accepted as a speaker for the program.

11568.description: We are looking for a competent volunteer, should be able to motivate and inspire. You must possess organizational skills and ability to communicate with students from diverse backgrounds and experience. The goal is to ensure that our organization is always staffed with the best and most reliable individuals, and that they are correctly positioned for the fulfillment of our program and their interest. Time Commitment Before Event: 2 hrs During Event: 40 hrs After Event: 5 Hrs Duties and responsibilities Before Event Sign MOU for copy right and media responsibilities Understand program logistics and role During Event Take pictures Take Videos Upload pictures to designated organization location Pick the best pictures for the final video Help create final video Perform social media posts through program After Event Create video of the event to be posted on YouTube channel and social media Post all images in our image library online **There may be other assignments that we would need to fill in accordance to your availability, skills, and interest. Qualifications Know how to use a professional digital camera (Nikon) Basic knowledge of any video editing program and/or website People skills Understanding of group dynamics Extra: Owns a camera Know a second language that is not English Working conditions Working with students at the upper middle school and high school level. Start Date July 16, 2018

11568.description: College Students attend our programs as mentors/coaches and facilitators of the learning experience for our students. During our CreatingSTEAM program, college student mentors are assigned to student groups to assist them in navigating the projects and meeting their deadlines, acting as both a guide and a facilitator through the process. If you would like more information about our mentoring program, please contact us at info@we-connect-the-dots.org
11568.title: College Students Wanted as Mentors for CreatingSTEAM Program

11568.description: CreatingSTEAM is a 10 day experiential learning program where students gain competencies in 21st century workforce skills and awareness of STEAM career opportunities for today and in the future. Teacher volunteers and students are involved in designing and teaching the sessions or co-teaching with STEAM industry experts. As a volunteer, you will help and mentor students by being interactive and supportive during the program when the students need help. You will have the opportunity to learn along the students and inspire them to be life-long learners. Other duties might include registration, setting up and cleaning up before and after the program as needed. Do I need to have technology skills to volunteer? No, technology skills are not required, but certainly are a plus if you have them. Either way you will learn through participating with the students. The most important skill or requirement is the desire to help students learn and motivate them to be successful. You will come away with new and valuable technology skills. Our program incorporates a variety of team building activities that support our goal to engage students to work collaboratively. The result is that by volunteering you will benefit from the experience and come away with valuable skills. To learn more about the opportunity at this link: http://we-connect-the-dots.org/creatingsteam/
11568.title: Teachers, are you looking for a learning experience that is rewarding too? CreatingSTEAM

07081.description: The Making Strides Against Breast Cancer of Ridgefield Park team is in search of a bright, energetic and talented volunteer photographer to capture the spirit of the Kickoff Breakfast taking place on Thursday August 2, 7am-9:30am. Our mission at the American Cancer Society is to save lives, to celebrate lives and lead the fight for a world without cancer. Making Strides Against Breast Cancer walks raise awareness and funds to save lives from breast cancer. Each event is a noncompetitive 3 to 5 mile walk that brings people together to make a difference for everyone who has been touched by breast cancer. The events raise money to fund innovative research, provide free information and support, and to help people reduce their breast cancer risk or find it early when it's most treatable. Interested? Please send resumes and portfolios to RidgefieldParkNJStrides@cancer.org no later than Friday, June 29th.
07081.title: Photographer- Making Strides Against Breast Cancer of Ridgefield Park

11735.description: The Jimmy Fund/Variety Children’s Charities Theatre Collections Program is looking for local movie lovers with big hearts and a few spare hours to help raise money for cancer care and research at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute this summer. Now in its 69th year, the program launched in 1949 and is the Jimmy Fund’s oldest annual fundraising effort. Since its inception the program has raised more than $30 million. Volunteers are needed Monday - Sunday, June 8 to July 28, at theaters in MA, RI, CT, NJ, NY and OH. Volunteers will pass collection canisters to guests in movie theatres following a brief Jimmy Fund trailer. All contributions go directly to the Jimmy Fund, which supports lifesaving adult and pediatric patient care and cancer research at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute. Volunteers can earn exciting incentives from a volunteer t-shirt, to complimentary National Amusements movie passes, to Blue Many Group or Boston Red Sox tickets ( while supplies last)! Volunteer and learn more today - www.jimmyfund.org/theatre .
11735.title: Volunteer for The Jimmy Fund at Farmingdale Multiplex in Farmingdale, NY!

11439.description: PeerFoward will connect 1.8 million students from low-income communities to college and career over the next decade. We do this by training influential high school students - Peer Leaders - to motivate their classmates over the school year to enroll in college. You can join PeerForward and help train these Peer Leaders at Summer Workshops on college campuses across the nation. Summer Workshops are the cornerstone of the PeerForward program. This is where the transformation occurs from student to Peer Leader. Training includes: Financial Aid 101 Developing a List of Good Fit Colleges Crafting a Personal Statement Four days on a college campus changes the trajectory of a student’s life. Eighty percent of students who attend a Summer Workshop enroll in college. In the past two decades, PeerForward has worked with 250,000 students from over 500 schools across the nation. PeerForward’s peer-to-peer model doubles the likelihood that a low-income student will enroll in college. You can help by volunteering as a Writing Coach or College Coach. For four days, Writing Coaches work in small teams of 8-10 students to jump start the college application process, beginning with the personal statement/essay and College Coaches work one-on-one with 8-10 students to help build a personalized list of good-fit colleges. Writing Coach: https://www.collegesummit.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/VOL-Writing-Coach-2018.pdf College Coach: https://www.collegesummit.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/VOL-College-Coach-2018.pdf By volunteering, you’ll participate in one of the most inspirational weekends of your life, connect to students and other volunteers in your community, receive free room & board for the entire Workshop, and most importantly, empower students from low-income communities to reach their true potential! Workshops will be hosted in Florida, New York, and Maryland. Check out the PeerForward website for specific dates and locations. If you’re interested, you can learn more about PeerFoward at http://www.peerforward.org/volunteer/. You can submit a volunteer application and register for a Workshop at https://college-summit.force.com/Volunteer/CSLogin. If you have any questions, please contact PeerForward’s Volunteer Engagement Coordinator, Jenadra Harvey, at jharvey@collegesummit.org.
11439.title: Connect Low-Income Students to College & Career at St. John's University this Summer!
