10004.description: Womankind works with survivors of gender-based violence to rise above trauma and build a path to healing. We bring critical resources and deep cultural competency to help Asian communities find refuge, recovery, and renewal. Purpose/Overview: The Later in Life program started in 2012 to address the needs and challenges of older adult (age 50 and above) survivors of gender-based violence. 20% of Womankind’s clients are above the age of 50; the LIL program works to ensure that their needs are represented both internally (through our services and staff) and externally (through our advocacy efforts). This position will support our outreach efforts to the Chinese population in Queens or Manhattan (depending on the volunteer’s preference), and will help with facilitating workshops and groups. There are two phases to this position. The first phase will require the volunteer to assist staff in reaching out to places that older Chinese adults frequent in an effort to establish a partnership. The second phase will initiate once the partnership is established. The volunteer will begin to conduct workshops and groups in the site. The larger goal of this position is twofold: first, to create awareness around abuse in later life and connect survivors with services; second, to foster an active aging lifestyle among older adults through the workshops and groups. Supervisor: Miyoung Kim, MS, MA, L-CAT, R-DMT, Expressive Therapies Ph.D. student/ Later in Life Advocate Location: This position will be based in either Queens or Manhattan, and will require traveling between the Womankind community office and a partnered organization (possibly senior center, adult day care center, etc.) Key Responsibilities: Visit locations in Queens/ Manhattan (around Womankind’s community office) that Chinese older adults frequent: senior centers, adult day care centers, etc. Build a partnership with at least one possible site for us to conduct workshops and groups Conduct workshops around abuse in later life at sites at least once a month Facilitate support groups at sites on a weekly basis (this can be art groups, dance groups, etc. - depends on the comfort level of the volunteer) Expected Time Commitment: May 2018 (or as soon as possible) through April 2019 Schedule: Two weekdays per week, 4 hours per day (minimum). In the beginning, the volunteer will use the two days to visit possible sites and go through trainings for this position. After establishing partnerships, the two days will revolve around facilitating groups/ workshops and supervision. Hours will be flexible during the two days depending on the partnerships established (most likely will be in the earlier part of the day). Qualifications: Must be proficient in Mandarin and/or Cantonese. Should have a strong interest in working with older adults. No prior experience with conducting workshops or facilitating groups required - trainings will be provided. An interest in wellness activities/therapy strongly preferred. Orientation and Training Requirements: Volunteer will receive ongoing supervision and training as needed throughout this position. In the first couple of months, the volunteer will receive these trainings before we execute the workshops and groups: Abuse in Later Life Training (which will cover the types of abuse that occur in later life, ageism, and active aging) How to conduct presentations training Facilitating groups training Any other Womankind trainings will be made available (and optional) for the volunteer Support/Continuing Education: Individual supervision will be provided on a weekly basis for at least an hour. Supervisor will guide the volunteer in reaching out to places and building professional relationships. Supervisor will also assist the volunteer in conducting workshops and facilitating wellness groups. Volunteer will also receive support from the Later in Life Program Manager as needed. Volunteer will participate in a monthly Later in Life team meeting. Benefits: Professional mentorship Supervision credits if volunteer is a LCAT candidate Gain experience with conducting workshops and public speaking Learn to create and facilitate wellness groups Opportunities for advancement within Womankind Opportunities for growth as volunteer will be equipped with tools to work with gender-based violence survivors Opportunities to teach specific skills if volunteer is passionate about certain creative activities (knitting, yoga, craft, dance, cooking, etc.) Selection process: Submit a resume and cover letter to the Later in Life Program Manager, Kayla Chan ( kchan@iamwk.org) with the email title \"Later in Life Volunteer\". Selected candidates will be contacted for an initial phone interview with the Later in Life Program Manager. Applications will be accepted until the position is filled.
10004.title: Later in Life Intern/Volunteer (Mandarin-Speaking)

10001.description: About the Institute The Institute for Immigrant Concerns (http://http://instituteforimmigrantconcerns.com/) is committed to equipping immigrant communities city-wide with English skills, computer training, job readiness, and referalls for social services. The Institute empowers immigrant families and communities in their quest for social and economic independence. To reach immigrants the Institute operates across New York City and frequently collaborates with other community groups. Our staff is as diverse as our clients and draws on talented individuals to create a powerful, sustainable impact in America's newest immigrants. Job Description The Bilingual Administrative Assistant is essential to maintaining an efficient office environment in support of Institute programs, staff, and volunteers. This position will be responsible for general office administration, organizing office resources, coordination of program activities, and program management support. This is an ideal position for those seeking administrative experience at a busy Manhattan non-profit. This program welcomes retired professionals. Though this position is primarily administrative, it presents an opportunity to get an introduction to non-profit management. Requirements: Commitment to work 3 months minimum Bilingual oral and written skills, preferably Russian but other languages welcome Excellent written and oral communication Knowledge of foreign languages Proficiency in MS Office and Excel Ability to work independently and alongside a team of staff and volunteers with a passion for immigrant empowerment Ability to work in a multi-cultural environment This internship is unpaid, but college credit may be available.
10001.title: Russian/Ukranian Speaking Program Assistant

10001.description: The Institute for Immigrant Concerns is looking for an office administrator/ program assistant with an interest in immigrant affairs and administrative skills. Duties will include: intake and registration of new students; assisting with document preparation and mailings; answering phone calls from students and teachers; monitoring expenses; and coordinating the volunteer program. We are flexible regarding schedule.
10001.title: Program Assistant

10001.description: Thank you for reading our ad! We are looking for enthusiastic and outgoing individuals who have an interest in nonprofit causes and fundraising. If that sounds like you continue reading! Responsibilities -Greet guests and check in with guest list ·Effectively communicate and deliver information regarding Maya’s Hope Organization. Skills ·Excellent Communication skills ·Charismatic personality with the ability to interact positively with our guest and actively engage all guests ·Enthusiastic and passionate; Interest in our cause Event details: Maya's Hope Yoga on the Roof DATE AND TIME Sunday, July 22 2 - 3 PM Time required for volunteers: 1:30 PM - 3 PM Volunteers who arrive late will not be allowed to volunteer. Thank you for your interest in helping us fundraise for the cutie pies at Maya's Hope.

10001.description: Assess systems on a regular basis to ensure it continues to meet necessary demands. Offer suggestions for possible upgrades and changes. Help managing and updating applications and programs. Being in the office for support with internet issues as needed.
10001.title: IT Specialist

10001.description: The Institute for Immigrant Concerns (http://http://instituteforimmigrantconcerns.com/) is committed to equipping immigrant communities city-wide with English skills, computer training, job readiness, and referrals for social services. The Institute empowers immigrant families and communities in their quest for social and economic independence. To reach immigrants the Institute operates across New York City and frequently collaborates with other community groups. Our staff is as diverse as our clients and draws on talented individuals to create a powerful, sustainable impact in America's newest immigrants. Job Description The Office Administrator will work closely alongside the Directors, ESOL instructors and support staff in order to maintain an efficient office environment. The Administrator will be responsible for general office administration, organizing office resources, coordination of program activities, and program management support. The role is crucial to the smooth running of our ESOL program: answering prospective students’ emails, being a point of contact for current students, sending out information for upcoming cycles, posting on social media as well as assisting with applying for grants. This is an ideal position for those seeking administrative experience at a busy Manhattan non-profit. Though this internship is primarily administrative, it presents an opportunity to get an introduction to non-profit management. Requirements: Commitment to work 6 months minimum Able to commit to 3 days per week (Monday-Thursday, 3-4 hours per day) Native or Advanced English speaker Excellent written and oral communication Excellent organizational skills and able to multi-task Proficiency in MS Office and Excel Familiar with social media (website, facebook, twitter) Ability to work independently and alongside a team of staff and volunteers with a passion for immigrant empowerment Ability to work in a multi-cultural environment Other languages would be helpful but are not essential (Spanish, French and Russian etc.) This internship is unpaid, but college credit may be available and references can be provided.
10001.title: Office Administrator

10001.description: The Institute for Immigrant Concerns is looking for an office administrator/ program assistant with an interest in immigrant affairs and Spanish-speaking skills. Duties will include: intake and registration of new students; assisting with document preparation and mailings; answering phone calls from students and teachers; monitoring expenses; and coordinating the volunteer program. We are flexible regarding schedule.
10001.title: Spanish Speaking Program Assistant

10001.description: PRO BONO NET SUMMER LEGAL INTERN: New York City Pro Bono Center & DisasterLegalAid.org About Pro Bono Net Pro Bono Net is a national non-profit organization dedicated to increasing access to justice through innovative technology solutions and collaborative partnerships that transform the way legal help reaches those in need. Our comprehensive programs enable the public interest legal community to make a stronger impact, increase volunteer lawyer participation, and provide resources and self-help tools that allow the public to understand their rights and resolve legal issues that threaten family security, livelihood and stability. To learn more about our programs, visit: http://www.probono.net/about/item.Mission. Description Pro Bono Net is looking for a legal intern to provide support for two key projects and will work closely with the staff attorneys that coordinate them: New York City Pro Bono Center: An online hub for lawyers, law students and legal professionals engaged in pro bono work in NYC. Specific tasks include: curating news and calendar events, working with our partners to publish our monthly newsletter/e-calendar, responding to membership requests and inquiries, and providing strategic and administrative support to the Pro Bono & Strategic Initiatives Coordinator as needed for the NYC Pro Bono Center and the broader probono.net/ny practice areas. org: A national website that provides legal rights information for people affected by disasters and resources for advocates serving those affected. Specific tasks include curating news and calendar events, assisting with the development of a social media presence (Facebook and Twitter), and providing general strategic and administrative support to our Disaster Response Legal Fellow as needed. The time commitment for this position is flexible, however the ideal candidate will work a minimum of 3 days per week for approximately 6-8 weeks. The intern should have a personal laptop available for use. This internship is unpaid. Requirements & Qualifications First and foremost, a strong interest in the access to justice movement and the use of technology therein, and a desire to learn about the work of the nonprofit legal-tech community in NYC and nationally. Detail oriented and highly organized, with ability to multitask, establish priorities and track projects. Strong communication and interpersonal skills. Pro-active attitude and ability to work independently with minimal supervision. Able to quickly learn new skills using software and above average proficiency with computers and technology. College students and law students are encouraged to apply. Application Instructions The internship is part-time, for no less than 3 days a week for at least 6 weeks, ideally to begin no later than July 9 th, 2018. The internship will be based out of Pro Bono Net’s office in Midtown Manhattan, but occasional remote work is a possibility. Email a resume, one page cover letter, and a short writing sample to jpenkoff@probono.net with the subject line: NYC/DLA Intern. Please note the hours and days you will be available to work. No calls please. Only those offered interviews will be contacted.
10001.title: Pro Bono Net - Summer Legal Volunteer/Intern

10001.description: Institute for Immigrant Concerns, a not-for-profit providing ESOL classes for adult immigrants and refugees, started in 1997, is looking for ESL instructors. Must have Bachelor's or MA Degree and at least 2 years of English teaching experience (whether domestic or abroad). Our students are all motivated and studious adults. We put great emphasis on survival English, employment and cross-cultural awareness. Applicants should be available twice a week, on Tuesdays and Thursdays for our morning classes ( 9am-12pm). We are currently looking for ESOL teachers for the 4-week summer cycle ( July 17-August 9), and welcome anyone with the potential of teaching future cycles. Applicants must send us a copy of their resume and a brief cover letter.
10001.title: ESOL Teachers for Adult Immigrants

10001.description: Volunteer with GripTape GripTape challenges the notion that learning must be adult-engineered and guided, and instead creates opportunities for young people to follow their passions - as inventors, designers, and producers- through the GripTape Learning Challenge. We work with underserved high school-aged youth (15-19 years old) to provide resources and support that enable them to actively construct their paths for success. It is inspiring to bear witness as youth grow and ignite their learning passions, and young people tell us again and again how empowering and transformative it is to have full control over their decisions with consistent support from a person who takes genuine, deep interest in their efforts. We’re currently seeking part-time volunteers who are committed to youth development to support GripTape young people. Serving as a \"Champion,\" this opportunity allows you to: Offer motivation and encouragement to youth who are driving their own learning Actively listen and encourage GripTape youth without guiding or advising their decision-making We provide approximately 3 hours of training by video conference. Champions hold virtual calls - Google Hangouts, Skype, FaceTime - with Challengers every few weeks during their learning journeys with youth across the U.S. for 1-3 months per learning cycle. Hours are flexible, with regular check-ins set around the schedules of the youth and Champion. To volunteer with GripTape, please sign up here.
10001.title: GripTape Learning Challenge

10001.description: The Sales & Merchandising Intern will play a critical supporting role in the detailed management of the product lifecycle process, in tracking purchase orders and product samples, in preparing weekly sales reports, and other deliverables to ensure key product development and financial deadlines are met. Responsibilities will include, but are not limited to: Reviewing and updating selling reports weekly, and helping prepare for bi-weekly best seller/business reviews Managing product placement and creating collections on GGP’s retail and wholesale website Creating and updating line sheets and e-catalogs Assisting in maintaining and merchandising the showroom and sample closet Staying abreast of industry trends and competitor activity through weekly market research, competitive shopping and analysis In addition to daily task, will learn about pricing, product development, retail math and more Qualifications: Available minimum 3 days per week, for 4 months, starting in May 2018 Interest in merchandising and sales Ability to work in a fast-paced, dynamic environment Strong organizational skills Proficient in Microsoft Excel and PowerPoint Must have a passionate curiosity and desire to learn about consumer and retail trends, including customer demographics, purchasing influencers, and emerging technology Specific Qualifications (but not necessary): Familiarity with Shopify SEO / SEM / Adwords Photoshop Location: 115 W 30th Street, Suite 400, New York Global Goods Partners is an equal opportunity employer _________________ Global Goods Partners is a non-profit, social enterprise based in NYC that is dedicated to alleviating poverty and promoting social justice by strengthening women-led development initiatives around the world. We partner with organizations, associations, and cooperatives worldwide that integrate their commitment to community development-specifically, improvements in education, health, women’s rights, and employment opportunities-with socially responsible income-generating enterprises. We create economic opportunity by offering design direction, generating demand, and bringing the unique, handmade, and quality fashion accessories that our more than 40 partners in 22 countries produce to the U.S. and international markets through our website, www.globalgoodspartners.org.
10001.title: Volunteer Sales & Merchandising Intern

10001.description: Do you love helping children and saving lives? Are you great at being creative and thinking outside of the box? Want to help us raise money and awareness for children in need? Then you might be just the person we are looking for! Maya’s Hope is searching for a summer Intern to help with events, administrative tasks, and other exciting creative projects! . Maya’s Hope is a 501(c)3 organization that works to improve the quality of life for disadvantaged, orphaned and extremely impoverished children around the world, with a current focus on the Philippines and Ukraine. This role offers the intern a total immersion into a busy non-profit. You will be given an opportunity to take on as much responsibility as you want and learn as much as you want, gain visibility for our organization, and help us raise the funds we need to continue our work. Key Duties -- Research Tax Letters Administrative tasks Help with events Help with social media Key Skills Required Proven written and verbal communication skills An interest in marketing, communications, and social media Strong familiarity with Google Suite (e.g. Excel, Word) An ability to consistently demonstrate integrity, hard work, and effectiveness An ability to remain calm under pressure and a robust/resilient attitude towards challenges Excellent attention to detail and a high motivation to learn Skill at prioritizing work and completing tasks An ability to work independently and think creatively Must show up on time. If this sounds like the internship for you, please send a cover letter and resume to maya@mayashope.org.
10001.title: Summer Internship to help children

10001.description: Thank you for your interest in Maya's Hope! Here's more about Maya's Hope: www.mayashope.org. Who should apply: Someone who has NYC event planning experience and has done events of 300 or more people. (Requirement: must have done NYC charity events and know the ins and outs of a silent auction!) When It’s flexible! We can work with your schedule, but you will need to be available all day and evening on Oct. 26th, the date of our Gala. And you will need to spend a day or part of a couple of days in our office soon for orientation. Venue: 583 Park Avenue About Maya’s Hope is a 501(c)3 organization that is dedicated to improving the lives of orphaned, special needs, and disenfranchised children on a global scale. We are looking for that special person who has experience recruiting, training and supervising volunteers for a New York City Gala. We have great volunteers; we just need you to organize their efforts to help make our annual Gala spectacular! This is our biggest fundraising event of the year and the cuties we help depend on its success. This is a part-time volunteer position that involves working both onsite and virtually. You should know how to use spreadsheets and google calendar in order to organize and schedule volunteer hours. If you have the Gala background, organizational and leadership skills, and enthusiasm we need for this important position, please send the following: 1) letter as to why you are perfect for this role 2) resume If you are a suitable candidate, we will contact you and please be prepared to provide three references who have worked with you at a charity gala. If you do not have experience with charity galas and silent auctions, you will not be considered. Thank you!
10001.title: Charity Gala Event Planner needed for October 27th (Pre-Planning involved)

10001.description: We are looking for amazing and exceptional individuals to join our host committee for the Maya's Hope Lotus Ball on Friday, October 26, 2018 at 583 Park Avenue! Maya's Hope improves the quality of life of disadvantaged, orphaned and extremely impoverished children around the world. This will be the 7th Annual Gala for Maya's Hope and you can help us reach our goal of $300,000! We are looking for individuals from a wide array of backgrounds: law, medicine, entrepreneurs, real estate, finance and those who want to make a difference! Here's what is required: -Purchase your ticket upon joining ($350.00) - Attend and actively participate in a majority of Committee Meetings In person participation is assumed although a conference call option will be available for those with special circumstances or last minute scheduling issues. - Commit to raising a minimum of $4,000 for the Gala through sponsorships, ticket sales, and auction items with the goal of securing at least one sponsor, one live auction item (Auction item needs include exotic vacation destinations, airfare, unique experiences such as celebrity chef-hosted house parties, rounds of golf with local celebrities, exclusive tickets to sporting or arts event, etc.) - Solicit sponsorships from at least five companies - Solicit in-kind donations such as graphic design and photography services, discounted printing, - Hand address and personalize invitations to at least 15 individuals from your personal network for the Gala. -Be Ambassadors of Maya's Hope -Have integrity and show respect to all volunteers, members of the committee, board and humankind :) If you meet these criteria, please send an email explaining why you would like to join and please attach a copy of your resume or LinkedIn page. Please email maya@mayashope.org. If selected, you will be part of an extraordinary event which directly impacts the lives of the children we serve. Here is a video from our 2017 gala: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zQyb8SHA02U&t=28s Here are photos from 2017 Gala: https://www.facebook.com/pg/MayasHope/photos/?tab=album&album_id=1748530808499062 We understand that not everyone has the time and resources to meet these expectations but still have a desire to help. To this end, there are other volunteer opportunities available for those individuals who are unable to commit to the full list of tasks outlined above.
10001.title: Host to Join Host Committee for Maya's Hope Lotus Ball 2018

10001.description: Do you love Instagram? Are you great at using social media effectively? Want to help us raise money and awareness for children in need? Then you might be just the person we are looking for! Maya’s Hope is searching for a Social Media Intern to coordinate and execute social media strategy and help with our accounts on Instagram, Facebook, and anywhere else we can get out the word about the Cutie Pies that we serve. . Maya’s Hope is a 501(c)3 organization that works to improve the quality of life for disadvantaged, orphaned and extremely impoverished children around the world, with a current focus on the Philippines and Ukraine. This role offers the intern a total immersion into a busy non-profit. You will be given an opportunity to take on as much responsibility as you want and learn as much as you want as you work to increase our social media presence, gain visibility for our organization, and help us raise the funds we need to continue our work. Key Duties -- Social Media Community Management Streamline company social media accounts (e.g. Facebook, Instagram, LinkedIn, etc.) to ensure uniform content and tone of voice Update accounts on YouTube, and any other appropriate social media platforms where we are not currently represented Increase our number of followers/donors by engaging with them on a daily basis Help create and design email broadcasts highlighting our activities and children Use polls and surveys to build our social media footprint and reputation Build Facebook 'likes’ by approaching potential supporters through other social media channels and email marketing campaigns Track key social media analytics on a monthly basis, including Google Analytics, Bitly statistics, LinkedIn company stats, etc. Key Skills Required Proven written and verbal communication skills An interest in marketing, communications, and social media Strong familiarity with key social media (e.g. Instagram and Facebook) and with Google Suite (e.g. Excel, Word) An ability to consistently demonstrate integrity, hard work, and effectiveness An ability to remain calm under pressure and a robust/resilient attitude towards challenges Excellent attention to detail and a high motivation to learn Skill at prioritizing work and completing tasks An ability to work independently and think creatively Must show up on time. J If this sounds like the internship for you, please send a cover letter and resume to maya@mayashope.org.
10001.title: Social Media and Instagram Intern

10001.description: Do you have a strong passion for the development of Africa? Do you have innovative ideas on how the youth can contribute to Africa’s development? Do you want to work directly with the African Development Bank, UNHabitat, the African Union, and the United Nations Economic Commission for Africa? Do you want to attend meetings at the UN Headquarters in New York? Do you love to network and meet people from all over the world? Then this position is for you! YALDA is a networking organization that is truly Africa branded : \"By Africans, For Africa!\". YALDA is a non-profit international organization established by Harvard University students in order to create a resourceful networking database for those with a strong interest in Africa. The network is centered around YALDA branches, primarily at African universities, and serves to increase the capacity of youth in Africa for developing positive leadership skills and to espouse an honest work ethic. YALDA US works on researching opportunities in Africa, fundraising activities, working with branches, maintaining relationships with UN and compliance with regulations as a 501 (c)(3). YALDA US is planning its annual fundraising event in New York and has vacancies for Event Management Interns to report directly to the YALDA US External Liaison Officer and YALDA US President. Please note this is an UNPAID internship. Brief: The YALDA US Event Management Intern is responsible for assisting the YALDA US Branch with planning and delivery of our fundraising event in New York. The purpose of event is to fund the YALDA Youth Hub being built in Botswana. If you love Africa and would love to see her develop, then this opportunity is for you! Responsibilities: Engage businesses, organizations and individuals for ticket sale purchases Engage local businesses and international organizations for event sponsorships Manage and assist in the coordination of activities during the event Create marketing materials and prepare team members for meetings by conducting research and developing strategies Coordinate activities with business partners and corporate sponsors Promote event in social media and other relevant platforms Knowledge, Skills and Experience: Previous experience in project management or event management Ability to work in a fast-paced environment Excellent attention to detail, organization skills and accuracy of work Ability to communicate in a professional manner and develop good rapport with both internal and external parties Work independently and tackle multiple proposals simultaneously Must have a strong interest in Africa Qualifications: This is a great opportunity for undergraduate, graduate students and working professionals Advanced PC skills; including Word, Excel, PowerPoint Other Candidates preferably located in New York, NY Must have constant and reliable access to internet www.yaldaus.org www.yaldafrica.org Please send your Resume and Cover Letter to yaldarecruit@gmail.com by 07 May 2018.Please quote \"YALDA US Event Management Intern\" in the subject line.
10001.title: YALDA US Event Management Intern
10001.org: Youth Alliance for Leadership and Development in Africa (YALDA)

Social Media and Web Responsibilities: Create content to grow the organization’s footprint, including social media and blog posts Research current artisan partners and product, maintain sample inventory Expand and maintain GGP’s social networking and online presence to promote GGP products, fundraising efforts, and stories of women artisan partners around the world. Create compelling narratives about GGP’s partners and work around the world. Research and update country and partner information currently on the website. Craft descriptive and appealing product descriptions for the website. PR and Events Responsibilities: Connect with influential media outlets and journalists to place stories about company news, relevant holidays, and collections Outreach to potential media partners with pitches, press releases and curated line sheets Actively pursue permanent links on like-minded sites, and assist with implementing social media strategy. Organize events designed to engage our target market. Develop and enact a strategy for digital communications with consumers and other key stakeholders to include artisan stories, product information, and resources. Personal Requirements: Excellent research, communication and writing skills Proficient in Microsoft Excel and PowerPoint Experience with social media, blogging and creating public relations campaigns Interest in and knowledge of fair trade and ethical business Able to commit to 2-3 days per week during the summer college break Specific Qualifications (a plus but not necessary): Experience in creating and implementing public relations campaigns, including familiarity with print and online media Proficiency with Photoshop, Shopify, SEO, Adwords Familiarity with e-mail marketing applications like vertical response Interest in fashion, design, or craft production Hours: 18-25 hours/week Email resume to sharrison@globalgoodspartners.org
10001.title: Marketing and Communications Intern

10001.description: Are you looking for employee engagement or team building activities for your company, department or group? Hudson Guild’s Corporate Volunteer Programs offer a wide array of opportunities. Hudson Guild is a multi-service community center serving those who live, work, or go to school in Chelsea, with a focus on those in need. With offerings as varied as community service projects for at-risk teens, mental health counseling for low-income individuals, wellness services for older adults, arts programming, and early childhood education for children, the Guild provides services to people in need and other activities to ensure a vibrant, safe, and healthy community. Please contact Rebecca Dealy at rdealy@hudsonguild.org or 212-760-9800 for more information!

10002.description: In conjunction with Henry Street's 125th anniversary, we will be celebrating with a large community day event alongside our annual Dunk & Donate basketball tournament. This exciting new opportunity will increase brand visibility for our sponsoring teams, as well as offer a wider variety of sponsorship options. Form a company or individual five-person basketball team and enter the tournament at the level of your choice - the higher the level, the bigger your impact on our youth programs and recognition of your team. Our sponsors will have the opportunity to play one-on-one with students from our Boys & Girls Republic program. Team names and logos will be featured on the tournament banner displayed in the park; on the event t-shirt; printed program and website, and in our press releases and social media marketing. We are looking for volunteers to provide fun activities for the younger children at our event. Volunteers will teach a small group of children an interesting craft, dance, etc. for a set time period, and repeat the process as the volunteers send their group over to the next station. The kids will be stamped, and once all groups have completed each station, they will be given a prize bag. This ensures participation and attention.
10002.title: Dunk and Donate Kids Activities Volunteers Needed!

10003.description: The nonprofit organization Let's Get Ready provides students from low-income circumstances and historically underrepresented backgrounds with free SAT preparation, college admissions counseling and assistance, as well as other support services necessary to gain admission to and graduate from college. We are looking for professionals from various career backgrounds to share their career experience and expertise with motivated, college-bound students at Let's Get Ready's summer Career Day. We welcome and encourage professionals from all backgrounds, but would be particularly grateful for volunteers in medical, engineering, fine arts, and journalistic professions. Career Day offers our students the opportunity to learn about diverse career fields and how they can take meaningful steps towards achieving their career goals. In addition, volunteers have the opportunity to mingle and network with other professionals while simultaneously making a difference in ambitious students' futures. Every year our students excitedly look forward to the Career Day, and we are hoping that you will join us in helping our students! Career Day will be held on Saturday, July 28th from 11am- 3pm at NYU Silver Center, 31 Washington Place, New York, NY, 10003. Volunteers are encouraged to share this opportunity with friends and colleagues who are likewise interested in volunteering. Volunteers may range in work experience from temporary interns to full-time employees to retired professionals. Interested volunteers may RSVP by filling out the following google form below and please send any questions, comments, or concerns to msheck@letsgetready.org. Thank you for considering volunteering with Let's Get Ready! https://goo.gl/forms/385MrARFfJ3vSrxU2
10003.title: Let's Get Ready Career Day 2018

10003.description: GO Project Summer Internship Powered by Echoing Green’s Work on Purpose Program HEART + HEAD = HUSTLE GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social, and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home, and in life. GO Getter Summer Internship: How YOU Can Help The GO Project summer internship is an opportunity for high school students to learn and develop leadership skills while working with GO Project students in academic and/or enrichment classes. During the 5-week GO Summer program, interns will be supporting instruction in one of our K -7 th grade classrooms under the guidance of a Head Teacher or Enrichment Teacher. Interns will work in small groups or one-to-one within the classroom to help students complete projects, remain focused, and build confidence as learners. Morning interns will provide support in an academic classroom setting for math and literacy. Afternoon interns will provide support in a particular enrichment activity, such as art, theater, ballet, hip-hop, capoeira, yoga, and more. Interns will also be participating in rigorous daily professional development sessions where Echoing Green’s book, Work on Purpose, will be used to help them discover and enhance their passions (HEART) and their talents (HEAD) to become change-making leaders in their community (HUSTLE). A strong social justice-centered curriculum and required readings will form the core framework for the internship. At the end of the summer, interns will have completed a portfolio with work from daily classroom and professional development sessions, co-led a professional development session, gained leadership skills, and developed a culminating Hustle project that they will showcase for other GO Project interns, staff members, board members, and community supporters. Time Commitment Attend mandatory orientation and trainings: Saturday, June 23 rd, Thursday, June 28 th, and Friday, June 29 th Commitment to the entire summer session is required. July 2 nd to August 3 rd, 2018, Monday-Friday, either the morning academic session (8:30am-2:00pm) or the afternoon enrichment session (12:00pm-5:30pm). Daily participation in professional development sessions. Location Berkeley Carroll School (701 Carroll Street, Brooklyn); or Grace Church School (86 Fourth Avenue, Manhattan); or Luke’s School (487 Hudson Street, Manhattan); or Grace Church High School (46 Cooper Square, Manhattan) Location and internship schedule will be assigned upon hire. Responsibilities Assist teachers and work one-to-one or in small groups with students who are in need of academic intervention. Actively engage with the students, teachers, fellow interns, and other program staff. Enthusiastically participate in daily professional development sessions. Attend all sessions punctually and consistently. Co-lead one professional development session during the summer. Contribute regularly to the volunteer blog. Read all assigned materials. Meet all internship deadlines. Benefits Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Development of leadership skills. Ongoing personal and professional development opportunities. Continual on-site support from GO Project staff. Portfolio for support with college and career selection. Completion of a service learning project which will have a larger impact on the community. Potential participation in the High School Student Leadership Council. Qualifications High school students in good academic standing (9 th-12 th graders). Commitment to and belief in all children’s ability to succeed and thrive. Commitment to social justice through educational equity. Ability to work collaboratively on a team. Strong or emerging leadership skills. Punctuality and professionalism. Application Process Complete online application form. Submit a personal statement explaining why you would like to intern with GO Project and reflecting on a social justice issue which you consider the most important (maximum 750 words). Submit a copy of your most recent school transcript. Provide one written letter of recommendation ( References can only be from teachers, employers, school administrators, or supervisors). Attend an interview as part of the initial screening process. Click here to access the online internship application. If you have any questions about the internship, please contact volunteering@goprojectnyc.org. Deadline for application submission will be Monday, May 14 th, 2018. Early applications are encouraged as space is limited. GO Project Summer Internship Powered by Echoing Green’s Work on Purpose Program HEART + HEAD = HUSTLE GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social, and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home, and in life. GO Getter Summer Internship: How YOU Can Help The GO Project summer internship is an opportunity for high school students to learn and develop leadership skills while working with GO Project students in academic and/or enrichment classes. During the 5-week GO Summer program, interns will be supporting instruction in one of our K -7 th grade classrooms under the guidance of a Head Teacher or Enrichment Teacher. Interns will work in small groups or one-to-one within the classroom to help students complete projects, remain focused, and build confidence as learners. Morning interns will provide support in an academic classroom setting for math and literacy. Afternoon interns will provide support in a particular enrichment activity, such as art, theater, ballet, hip-hop, capoeira, yoga, and more. Interns will also be participating in rigorous daily professional development sessions where Echoing Green’s book, Work on Purpose, will be used to help them discover and enhance their passions (HEART) and their talents (HEAD) to become change-making leaders in their community (HUSTLE). A strong social justice-centered curriculum and required readings will form the core framework for the internship. At the end of the summer, interns will have completed a portfolio with work from daily classroom and professional development sessions, co-led a professional development session, gained leadership skills, and developed a culminating Hustle project that they will showcase for other GO Project interns, staff members, board members, and community supporters. Time Commitment Attend mandatory orientation and trainings: Saturday, June 23 rd, Thursday, June 28 th, and Friday, June 29 th Commitment to the entire summer session is required. July 2 nd to August 3 rd, 2018, Monday-Friday, either the morning academic session (8:30am-2:00pm) or the afternoon enrichment session (12:00pm-5:30pm). Daily participation in professional development sessions. Location Berkeley Carroll School (701 Carroll Street, Brooklyn); or Grace Church School (86 Fourth Avenue, Manhattan); or Luke’s School (487 Hudson Street, Manhattan); or Grace Church High School (46 Cooper Square, Manhattan) Location and internship schedule will be assigned upon hire. Responsibilities Assist teachers and work one-to-one or in small groups with students who are in need of academic intervention. Actively engage with the students, teachers, fellow interns, and other program staff. Enthusiastically participate in daily professional development sessions. Attend all sessions punctually and consistently. Co-lead one professional development session during the summer. Contribute regularly to the volunteer blog. Read all assigned materials. Meet all internship deadlines. Benefits Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Development of leadership skills. Ongoing personal and professional development opportunities. Continual on-site support from GO Project staff. Portfolio for support with college and career selection. Completion of a service learning project which will have a larger impact on the community. Potential participation in the High School Student Leadership Council. Qualifications High school students in good academic standing (9 th-12 th graders). Commitment to and belief in all children’s ability to succeed and thrive. Commitment to social justice through educational equity. Ability to work collaboratively on a team. Strong or emerging leadership skills. Punctuality and professionalism. Application Process Complete online application form. Submit a personal statement explaining why you would like to intern with GO Project and reflecting on a social justice issue which you consider the most important (maximum 750 words). Submit a copy of your most recent school transcript. Provide one written letter of recommendation ( References can only be from teachers, employers, school administrators, or supervisors). Attend an interview as part of the initial screening process. Click here to access the online internship application. If you have any questions about the internship, please contact volunteering@goprojectnyc.org. Deadline for application submission will be Monday, May 14 th, 2018. Early applications are encouraged as space is limited. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home, and in life. 10003.description: We are currently looking for Volunteer Office Assistants to work in the afternoon and/or the evening. Volunteer Office Assistants serve 4-6 hours per week for a prestigious downtown NYC community theater that produces 25-30 new plays and 3 free community events each year. Volunteer Office Assistants will answer phones, take reservations, file papers and occasionally assist Executive Director Crystal Field by writing letters or researching on the internet. Opportunities available specifically on weekdays in the Morning/Afternoons from 10am to 4pm, or in the evenings from 4pm to 10pm, or on weekends from 12pm to 8pm. Volunteers will receive FREE tickets to all TNC productions.
10003.title: Administrative Assistance

Do you have a caring heart and extra space in your home? AnB Education is looking for you! Make a difference today and host an international student! All our students need is: A Private bedroom with a desk, bed and dresser 2 meals a day on school days and 3 meals a day on non school days Transportation to and from school if there is no school buses provided Please contact AnB Headquarters office at: 267.263.2481 or email to contact@anbeducation.com Company website: www.anbeducation.com

11206.title: Gala Planning Committee

11206.description: Mentoring Kids Through Tennis Kings County Tennis League (KCTL) is a registered 501c3 non-profit that uses tennis as an instrument for mentorship and community building in Bedford Stuyvesant, Brooklyn. We literally bring tennis to the children’s communities. KCTL is seeking enthusiastic individuals who are comfortable working with kids and ready to develop their roles as mentors.Tennis skills are helpful, but not required. For the summer season, our free classes are Saturday mornings, June 2 through September 22, at the following sites in Bedford Stuyvesant, BK: Lafayette Gardens, Marcy, Sumner, Tompkins and Jackie Robinson. Volunteers must commit to a minimum number of classes. Duties for each class included: tossing tennis balls, giving out high fives, directing and communicating with students, and teaching If you have a tennis background. Basically, however, you will serve as a positive role model that the kids look forward to seeing each day. All volunteers are required to undergo a background check and training. Volunteers will receive a KCTL team jersey and invites to special volunteer events as a thanks for all their hard work. Please fill out a KCTL registration form if you’re interested, or contact rob@kingscountytennisleague.org.
11206.title: Mentor Kids through After-School Tennis

10009.description: Join us on Saturday, July 28th, from 9:00 AM - 12:00 PM for a special edition Green Team Event at our Community Compost Facility near 34th street. Don't miss this opportunity for an inside look at our industrial composting operation and vegetable garden. Projects will include amending soil into perennial beds, processing/screening compost and tending to the vegetable beds. Water, snacks, gloves, tools and materials all provided by Hudson River Park. Please submit a request on Volunteermatch to attend and we will follow up with more details if space is available.
10009.title: HRPK Green Team - July 28th

07869.description: Volunteers at iCan Bike-Randolph,NJ have an opportunity to help a person with a disability become an independent rider on a two wheeled bike in one week. Physically fit volunteers, 15 and older, will act as spotters and will walk/jog alongside the rider. Each day there are five, 75 minute sessions. Volunteers are requested to sign up for one or more sessions, Monday through Friday so they can work with the same person all week. Volunteers assist the rider to learn to ride by keeping their balance, steer, and offer encouragement and praise for their efforts. Volunteers and riders develop a friendship and share in the rider's success at the end of the week. This achievement creates a gateway of opportunity for socialization as well as participating in a healthy activity which in turn contributes to a healthy lifestyle. This helps them gain assurance and self-reliance in many other aspects of their lives with an \"I CAN\" attitude. We have seen from our volunteering at another iCan Bike Camp that volunteers left each day with a smile, having gained as much satisfaction as the riders knowing they have contributed to another's happiness. For videos, go to: www.icanshine.org/ican-bike-randolph-nj
07869.title: iCan Bike-Randolph, NJ

07869.description: We want volunteers like you to help make the ride a success. Volunteers are needed to help with ride weekend on Saturday, September 15th from 7AM - 11AM at Randolph, NJ. To sign-up visit http://bit.ly/BikeMSCountryChallenge2018 or email Michelle Almeida at Michelle.Almeida@nmss.org. We can’t wait to hear from you! When: September 15th from 7AM to 11AM Where: Randolph, NJ. How: To register, Visit http://bit.ly/BikeMSCountryChallenge2018 or Email Michelle.Almeida@nmss.org Thank you for your support!
07869.title: Cheer at Bike MS: Country Challenge's Randolph, NJ Rest Stop!
07869.org: National Multiple Sclerosis Society - New Jersey Metro Chapter

10474.description: The Knowledge House (TKH) is always looking for new Workshop Facilitator or Panelist for our Volunteer Initiative Program (VIP). As a Workshop Facilitator or Panelist, you will have the opportunity to work with current and aspiring technologists, creatives, and entrepreneurs in and around the Bronx. Our next volunteer opportunity is on July 26, 2018, for a freelancers' resource seminar & panel discussion we will be holding for our student/alumni network and other freelancers in and around the Bronx community. Part of the workshop will consist of a panel discussion where the following topics will be covered: Finding inspiration Branding your business/service Building clientele Time management & productivity tools The second part of the seminar will cover the topics: Freelancing ethics Contracts Taxes NYC Freelancer laws We are looking for panelists for the first part of the event, specifically freelancers who live or work in New York. Volunteers should: Currently, be working in technology (full-time, part-time, contract/freelance), or should have experience in one of the following capacities: Software Development. / Software Engineering UX / UI Design Graphic Design Product Management / Project Management IT / Quality Assurance Cyber Security Digital Marketing Entrepreneurship or, Other tech-facing roles in various industries Have experience working in teams (Comfortable with public speaking is a plus) ​
10474.title: Freelancers Resource Seminar Panelist

10573.description: Open Door Family Medical Center is partnering with Feeding Westchester (formerly the Food Bank of Westchester), to bring a free \"market on wheels\" to the Port Chester Community. Each month fresh, nutritious food will be provided to those-in-need. The food is set up as a farmer’s market so that people can walk through and select their own food, including fresh protein, dairy, produce and grains! Volunteers will help set up and distribute food products along with breaking down cardboard boxes. Location: Open Door Family Medical Center 5 Grace Church St, Port Chester, NY (Mobile Pantry in Parking Lot on Purdy St) Requirements: Able to lift 30 lbs. Spanish Language Skills beneficial High School Students Welcome! On-line Application Completed When: One Saturday a month July 28th, August 25th, Sept. 15th, October 13th, November 10th, December For additional information, please contact Jane Levy, Manager of Volunteer Programs: jlevy@odfmc.org.
10573.title: FREE Nutritious Food - Help Distribute at Mobile Pantry
10573.org: Open Door Family Medical Centers Inc

10573.description: Volunteer Judge for Subaru Story Contest At The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society (LLS), we're passionate about our mission: to cure leukemia, lymphoma, Hodgkin's disease and myeloma, and improve the quality of life of patients and their families. LLS volunteers help carry out this mission in so many ways: supporting patients, family members, healthcare professionals, and our community, driving policy advocacy, participating in our campaigns, and helping LLS build much needed capacity. Position Summary Volunteers in this role will report to Robin Plonsker, National Director, Institutional Giving, and Teri Johnson, Vice President, Volunteer Engagement. The outcomes of this role serve our mission by rewarding those LLS chapters who went above and beyond in implementing the Subaru \"Loves to Care\" program in their chapter. This is the third consecutive year that Subaru has chosen LLS to be its partner for their annual Loves to Care\" program. Through this program, LLS and Subaru retailers together are delivering more than 40,000 blankets, 7,700 arts & crafts kits and thousands of messages of hope to cancer patients across the nation during the months of June and July. Importantly, they also captured stories of impact while making these deliveries. In this role, volunteers will help determine which five LLS chapters will each receive $10,000 for submitting the most compelling Subaru \"Loves to Care\" stories. This role will require the volunteer to read and use a five-point rubric to score the top 20 stories (each of them 1-4 paragraphs) submitted by LLS chapters. Location This work can be completed remotely. Time Commitment This project is anticipated to take approximately 2-4 hours to complete. Project starts on or about August 15, 2018, and the work must be completed no later than August 24, 2018. Qualifications Volunteer should possess the following skills/qualifications: Able to read and fairly evaluate stories using a five-point rubric. Background check required: No Benefits Access to inspiring stories of LLS-Subaru impact on patients and their families Satisfaction of making a difference for LLS chapters Interested volunteers should contact Robin Plonsker, robin.plonsker@lls.org or volunteersryebrook@lls.org
10573.title: Volunteer Judge for Subaru Story Contest

11249.description: Our goal is to improve diagnosis and treatment for the most common chronic illness in the US - autoimmune disease. We are planning a fund raising event in New York City and are looking for someone to help organize it. Times are in reality more flexible than posted. We need an individual with passion, intelligence and initiative. This is a volunteer opportunity but if the fundraiser is successful it could lead to paid employment with ARI.
11249.title: Manager for NYC Fundraising Event

08857.description: KiDz HuB Media Network and Neverland Natives Visuals are looking for dedicated volunteers to help plan our first ever KiDz HuB Regional Film Festival! We're looking for volunteers that are passionate about getting kids involved in the arts and are able to put in hard work in order to get a recently announced festival prepared by the end of the summer. We have two general interest meetings from 4-5 on June 14 and June 21st at the address provided in our Location section. After that, we will have meetings every Thursday night from 5-7 in order to prepare for our festival on August 10th. Volunteers work closely with the event staff to plan the festival itinerary and distribute promotional materials to local businesses. Hopefully, we'll see you there!
08857.title: KiDz HuB Regional Film Festival NEEDS Volunteers!

08857.description: Hi Volunteer, We are very excited to announce our launch of Healthy Kids Running Series (HKRS) in Old Bridge this Fall and Next Spring and would love to have your support. We will be seeking the help of volunteers to be responsible for stretching runners, leading warm-ups, helping with on-site registration, marshaling the course, etc. We are therefore providing opportunities to promote a healthy lifestyle for kids, tweens, and teens, to meet our neighbors and make friends while providing volunteer opportunities? KiDz HuB has applied to be the Community Coordinators for the Healthy Kids Running Series in Old Bridge and we would be honored to have you as part of our team, to help to make this successful. Healthy Kids Running Series is a great way to spend time in the community and meet other families in your town. All volunteers will receive an HKRS KiDz HuB tech shirt for your help! Please sign up to volunteer with us for the Healthy Kids Running Series (HKRS) in the Fall and Spring Thanks ORLANDO \"Uncle Lanze\" DILLON Founder/Director | KiDz HuB Media Network Inc. Tel :732 HuB z HuB or 732 482 9482 Ext. 1002 | email o.dillon@kidzhub.org KiDz HuB | 3171 US Highway 9 North | Suite 317, Old Bridge NJ 08857 Facebook- www.facebook.com/KiDzHuB Twitter- www.twitter.com/ KiDzHuB Instagram- www.instagram.com/ KiDzHuB YouTube- www.youtube.com/ KiDzHuB Website- www.KiDzHuB.com
08857.title: Healthy Kids Running Series - Old Bridge NJ #HKRS

06902.description: Domus Gym Night launched July 1 at our Lockwood Avenue location. Meant to offer a safe and fun place for teens to spend the hours between work or school and bedtime, we've been interviewing participants about the kinds of services and activities they'd like to see in addition to basketball. As a result, beginning at 6:00p, August 8, Spoken Word Night will launch and we're looking for food volunteers to to help make the evening festive. These are teenage boys and girls, so hotdogs in a blanket, guac and chips, hummus and carrots are right up their alley. If you have the time to make and drop off a dish for 10 people, we'd appreciate it. And please consider staying for a while. Every poet needs an audience. To know more, write me.
06902.title: Spoken Word Night

06903.description: Welcome Visitors to the Museum; answer questions about Exhibits; respond to Phone Inquiries. Docent training provided at the start of each new exhibit. Time Commitment: Minimum 3 hours per week, during Museum hours. This is an especially good volunteer opportunity for students both during summer vacation time as well as fulfilling their school community service requirements.This position can be filled by students giving one Saturday afternoon a month to the Society. Seniors looking to meet new people and continue learning about their community have found this to be an interesting way to accomplish those goals. We are flexible in that volunteers can come in weekly or biweekly depending on their schedules.
06903.title: Docent

06903.description: Assistant Treasurer with the following duties: Reviews weekly cash deposits Receive, organize and pay bills Input accounting activity into Quickbooks Closing accounting books on monthly, quarterly and annual basis Organizing and archiving financial records Hours are flexible: Thursday, Fridays & Saturdays between 10:00 and 12:00 If you fit the bill and would like to help us, please get in touch with me. Thanks for your interest! Tom Porter Volunteer Coordinator - Board Member Stamford History Center 1508 High Ridge Road Stamford, CT 06903 www.stamfordhistory.org volunteer@stamfordhistory.org (O) 203-329-1183 (C) 917-701-3572
06903.title: Assistant Treasurer / Bookeeper

06903.description: Media/News Writer Volunteer, If you enjoy writing, this is the volunteer job for you. We are looking for someone to create press releases about the Stamford History Center for distribution to various media outlets (onlinenews sites, radio, tv, magazines, etc.). You will interview people in the organization to gather information. Once your article is reviewed by our volunteer editors, it will be sent out. It is essential that our media volunteer stays up-to- date with our activities, so press releases go out in a timely fashion. The position can be expanded to include the creation of newsletters and flyers (working with our graphic designer). This is a job that can be done largely from your own laptop/desktop, and at your own convenience. REQUIREMENT: Please write a two or three paragraph \"Press Release\" on one of the following topics: 1] About our Tag Sale 2] The opening of the Hoyt-Barnum House or 3] A past Historical Center event You can get ideas by going to our web site: www.stamfordhistory.org Forward it to me and we will review and get back to you. Thanks again for your interest in joining the volunteer team! Tom Tom Porter Volunteer Coordinator Stamford History Center 1508 High Ridge Road Stamford, CT 06903 www.stamfordhistory.org 203-329-1183 Skills needed: organized, experienced writer; a self-starter who can use Word and navigate the internet.
06903.title: Media/News Writer Volunteer

06903.description: Historic Home Docent & Museum Greeter We are looking for volunteers who would like to introduce visitors to our 1699 historic house museum, The Hoyt-Barnum House. You would be involved with greeting visitors with a smile and giving a brief explanation of the Center's offerings: a research library, photo archive, our current exhibit, and our historic house museum. People who wish to tour Hoyt-Barnum House first view an introductory film before starting the audio tour. You would be responsible for selling tickets and recording transactions, giving guests their audio pods and collecting them after the tours, opening and closing up the house museum, and monitoring visitors while they are in the house. Minimal training is needed. Museum Docents should be friendly and personable. They should be physically able to manage stairs and brief walks on a regular basis. Docents should be at least 20 years old and able to work at least one four-hour day, 2 x /month. Docents are needed for Thursdays and Fridays. Shifts are from noon to 3:15 pm on Thursdays and Fridays. Two docents are needed on Saturday: one from 10:30 - 1:00 and one from1:00 to 3:30 pm. You are welcome to stay longer to meet our other volunteers and make use of our facility. Check out our Website for loads of fun information: http://stamfordhistory.org/ Skills needed: -Basic math/money skills Hope to hear from you soon! Tom Tom Porter Volunteer Coordinator & Board Member Stamford History Center 1508 High Ridge Road Stamford, CT 06903 www.stamfordhistory.org volunteer@stamfordhistory.org (O) 203-329-1183 (C) 917-701-3572
06903.title: Stamford Historic Home - Tour Guide (No experience needed)

06901.description: New Volunteer orientation session will provide an overview of the Domestic Violence Crisis Center services, volunteer opportunities available, information on how to become a certified volunteer allowing one to work with victims of DV and completion of necessary paperwork to join the DVCC volunteer team.
06901.title: New volunteer orientation

06901.description: Stamford Academy serves about 135 high school students who have been unsuccessful in other schools. The number of students with Individual Education Plans (IEPs) is about twice the rate of Stamford Public Schools, yet Stamford is able to provide only one SPED teacher. You know how important one-on-one instruction is. Do you have a couple of hours to spare once a week during the school year to help tutor a student? Training provided. To meet our kids is to love them. They are wary and giving; have big dreams and struggle to stay on task; are talented and funny; and may have not had dinner the night before. If you'd like to know more, please contact me.
06901.title: Do you know what an IEP is? If so, read on...
